1.text: In those days John the Baptist came into the wilderness of Judea proclaiming,

2.text: “Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is near.”

3.text: For he is the one about whom Isaiah the prophet had spoken: “The voice of one shouting in the wilderness, ‘Prepare the way for the Lord, make his paths straight.’”

4.text: Now John wore clothing made from camel’s hair with a leather belt around his waist, and his diet consisted of locusts and wild honey.

5.text: Then people from Jerusalem, as well as all Judea and all the region around the Jordan, were going out to him,

6.text: and he was baptizing them in the Jordan River as they confessed their sins.

7.text: But when he saw many Pharisees and Sadducees coming to his baptism, he said to them, “You offspring of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the coming wrath?

8.text: Therefore produce fruit that proves your repentance,

9.text: and don’t think you can say to yourselves, ‘We have Abraham as our father.’ For I tell you that God can raise up children for Abraham from these stones!

10.text: Even now the ax is laid at the root of the trees, and every tree that does not produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.

11.text: “I baptize you with water, for repentance, but the one coming after me is more powerful than I am – I am not worthy to carry his sandals. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire.

12.text: His winnowing fork is in his hand, and he will clean out his threshing floor and will gather his wheat into the storehouse, but the chaff he will burn up with inextinguishable fire.”

13.text: Then Jesus came from Galilee to John to be baptized by him in the Jordan River.

14.text: But John tried to prevent him, saying, “I need to be baptized by you, and yet you come to me?”

15.text: So Jesus replied to him, “Let it happen now, for it is right for us to fulfill all righteousness.” Then John yielded to him.

16.text: After Jesus was baptized, just as he was coming up out of the water, the heavens opened and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove and coming on him.

17.text: And a voice from heaven said, “This is my one dear Son; in him I take great delight.”

1.text: Then Jesus was led by the Spirit into the wilderness to be tempted by the devil.

2.text: After he fasted forty days and forty nights he was famished.

3.text: The tempter came and said to him, “If you are the Son of God, command these stones to become bread.”

4.text: But he answered, “It is written, ‘Man does not live by bread alone, but by every word that comes from the mouth of God*.’”

5.text: Then the devil took him to the holy city, had him stand on the highest point of the temple,

6.text: and said to him, “If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down. For it is written, ‘He will command his angels concerning you’ and ‘with their hands they will lift you up, so that you will not strike your foot against a stone.’”

7.text: Jesus said to him, “Once again it is written: ‘You are not to put the Lord your God to the test.’”

8.text: Again, the devil took him to a very high mountain, and showed him all the kingdoms of the world and their grandeur.

9.text: And he said to him, “I will give you all these things if you throw yourself to the ground and worship me.”

10.text: Then Jesus said to him, “Go away, Satan! For it is written: ‘You are to worship the Lord your God and serve only him.’”

11.text: Then the devil left him, and angels came and began ministering to his needs.

12.text: Now when Jesus heard that John had been imprisoned, he went into Galilee.

13.text: While in Galilee, he moved from Nazareth by the sea, in the region of Zebulun and Naphtali,

14.text: so that what was spoken by Isaiah the prophet would be fulfilled:

15.text: “Land of Zebulun and land of Naphtali, the way by the sea, beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles –

16.text: the people who sit in darkness have seen a great light, and on those who sit in the region and shadow of death a light has dawned.”

17.text: From that time Jesus began to preach this message: “Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is near.”

18.text: As he was walking by the Sea of Galilee he saw two brothers, Simon (called Peter) and Andrew his brother, casting a net into the sea (for they were fishermen).

19.text: He said to them, “Follow me, and I will turn you into fishers of people.”

20.text: They left their nets immediately and followed him.

21.text: Going on from there he saw two other brothers, James the son of Zebedee and John his brother, in a boat with Zebedee their father, mending their nets. Then he called them.

22.text: They immediately left the boat and their father and followed him.

23.text: Jesus went throughout all of Galilee, teaching in their synagogues, preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing all kinds of disease and sickness among the people.

24.text: So a report about him spread throughout Syria. People brought to him all who suffered with various illnesses and afflictions, those who had seizures, paralytics, and those possessed by demons, and he healed them.

25.text: And large crowds followed him from Galilee, the Decapolis, Jerusalem, Judea, and beyond the Jordan River.

1.text: “Be careful not to display your righteousness merely to be seen by people. Otherwise you have no reward with your Father in heaven.

2.text: Thus whenever you do charitable giving, do not blow a trumpet before you, as the hypocrites do in synagogues and on streets so that people will praise them. I tell you the truth, they have their reward.

3.text: But when you do your giving, do not let your left hand know what your right hand is doing,

4.text: so that your gift may be in secret. And your Father, who sees in secret, will reward you.

5.text: “Whenever you pray, do not be like the hypocrites, because they love to pray while standing in synagogues and on street corners so that people can see them. Truly I say to you, they have their reward.

6.text: But whenever you pray, go into your room, close the door, and pray to your Father in secret. And your Father, who sees in secret, will reward you.

7.text: When you pray, do not babble repetitiously like the Gentiles, because they think that by their many words they will be heard.

8.text: Do not be like them, for your Father knows what you need before you ask him.

9.text: So pray this way: Our Father in heaven, may your name be honored,

10.text: may your kingdom come, may your will be done on earth as it is in heaven.

11.text: Give us today our daily bread,

12.text: and forgive us our debts, as we ourselves have forgiven our debtors.

13.text: And do not lead us into temptation, but deliver us from the evil one.

14.text: “For if you forgive others their sins, your heavenly Father will also forgive you.

15.text: But if you do not forgive others, your Father will not forgive you your sins.

16.text: “When you fast, do not look sullen like the hypocrites, for they make their faces unattractive so that people will see them fasting. I tell you the truth, they have their reward.

17.text: When you fast, put oil on your head and wash your face,

18.text: so that it will not be obvious to others when you are fasting, but only to your Father who is in secret. And your Father, who sees in secret, will reward you.

19.text: “Do not accumulate for yourselves treasures on earth, where moth and rust destroy and where thieves break in and steal.

20.text: But accumulate for yourselves treasures in heaven, where moth and rust do not destroy, and thieves do not break in and steal.

21.text: For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.

22.text: “The eye is the lamp of the body. If then your eye is healthy, your whole body will be full of light.

23.text: But if your eye is diseased, your whole body will be full of darkness. If then the light in you is darkness, how great is the darkness!

24.text: “No one can serve two masters, for either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and money.

25.text: “Therefore I tell you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat or drink, or about your body, what you will wear. Isn’t there more to life than food and more to the body than clothing?

26.text: Look at the birds in the sky: They do not sow, or reap, or gather into barns, yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Aren’t you more valuable than they are?

27.text: And which of you by worrying can add even one hour to his life?

28.text: Why do you worry about clothing? Think about how the flowers of the field grow; they do not work or spin.

29.text: Yet I tell you that not even Solomon in all his glory was clothed like one of these!

30.text: And if this is how God clothes the wild grass, which is here today and tomorrow is tossed into the fire to heat the oven, won’t he clothe you even more, you people of little faith?

31.text: So then, don’t worry saying, ‘What will we eat?’ or ‘What will we drink?’ or ‘What will we wear?’

32.text: For the unconverted pursue these things, and your heavenly Father knows that you need them.

33.text: But above all pursue his kingdom and righteousness, and all these things will be given to you as well.

34.text: So then, do not worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow will worry about itself. Today has enough trouble of its own.

1.text: “Do not judge so that you will not be judged.

2.text: For by the standard you judge you will be judged, and the measure you use will be the measure you receive.

3.text: Why do you see the speck in your brother’s eye, but fail to see the beam of wood in your own?

4.text: Or how can you say to your brother, ‘Let me remove the speck from your eye,’ while there is a beam in your own?

5.text: You hypocrite! First remove the beam from your own eye, and then you can see clearly to remove the speck from your brother’s eye.

6.text: Do not give what is holy to dogs or throw your pearls before pigs; otherwise they will trample them under their feet and turn around and tear you to pieces.

7.text: “Ask and it will be given to you; seek and you will find; knock and the door will be opened for you.

8.text: For everyone who asks receives, and the one who seeks finds, and to the one who knocks, the door will be opened.

9.text: Is there anyone among you who, if his son asks for bread, will give him a stone?

10.text: Or if he asks for a fish, will give him a snake?

11.text: If you then, although you are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father in heaven give good gifts to those who ask him!

12.text: In everything, treat others as you would want them to treat you, for this fulfills the law and the prophets.

13.text: “Enter through the narrow gate, because the gate is wide and the way is spacious that leads to destruction, and there are many who enter through it.

14.text: But the gate is narrow and the way is difficult that leads to life, and there are few who find it.

15.text: “Watch out for false prophets, who come to you in sheep’s clothing but inwardly are voracious wolves.

16.text: You will recognize them by their fruit. Grapes are not gathered from thorns or figs from thistles, are they?

17.text: In the same way, every good tree bears good fruit, but the bad tree bears bad fruit.

18.text: A good tree is not able to bear bad fruit, nor a bad tree to bear good fruit.

19.text: Every tree that does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.

20.text: So then, you will recognize them by their fruit.

21.text: “Not everyone who says to me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ will enter into the kingdom of heaven – only the one who does the will of my Father in heaven.

22.text: On that day, many will say to me, ‘Lord, Lord, didn’t we prophesy in your name, and in your name cast out demons and do many powerful deeds?’

23.text: Then I will declare to them, ‘I never knew you. Go away from me, you lawbreakers!’

24.text: “Everyone who hears these words of mine and does them is like a wise man who built his house on rock.

25.text: The rain fell, the flood came, and the winds beat against that house, but it did not collapse because it had been founded on rock.

26.text: Everyone who hears these words of mine and does not do them is like a foolish man who built his house on sand.

27.text: The rain fell, the flood came, and the winds beat against that house, and it collapsed; it was utterly destroyed!”

28.text: When Jesus finished saying these things, the crowds were amazed by his teaching,

29.text: because he taught them like one who had authority, not like their experts in the law.

1.text: Now when they approached Jerusalem and came to Bethphage, at the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two disciples,

2.text: telling them, “Go to the village ahead of you. Right away you will find a donkey tied there, and a colt with her. Untie them and bring them to me.

3.text: If anyone says anything to you, you are to say, ‘The Lord needs them,’ and he will send them at once.”

4.text: This took place to fulfill what was spoken by the prophet:

5.text: “Tell the people of Zion, ‘Look, your king is coming to you, unassuming and seated on a donkey, and on a colt, the foal of a donkey.’”

6.text: So the disciples went and did as Jesus had instructed them.

7.text: They brought the donkey and the colt and placed their cloaks on them, and he sat on them.

8.text: A very large crowd spread their cloaks on the road. Others cut branches from the trees and spread them on the road.

9.text: The crowds that went ahead of him and those following kept shouting, “Hosanna to the Son of David! Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the highest!”

10.text: As he entered Jerusalem the whole city was thrown into an uproar, saying, “Who is this?”

11.text: And the crowds were saying, “This is the prophet Jesus, from Nazareth in Galilee.”

12.text: Then Jesus entered the temple area and drove out all those who were selling and buying in the temple courts, and turned over the tables of the money changers and the chairs of those selling doves.

13.text: And he said to them, “It is written, ‘My house will be called a house of prayer,’ but you are turning it into a den of robbers!”

14.text: The blind and lame came to him in the temple courts, and he healed them.

15.text: But when the chief priests and the experts in the law saw the wonderful things he did and heard the children crying out in the temple courts, “Hosanna to the Son of David,” they became indignant

16.text: and said to him, “Do you hear what they are saying?” Jesus said to them, “Yes. Have you never read, ‘Out of the mouths of children and nursing infants you have prepared praise for yourself’?”

17.text: And leaving them, he went out of the city to Bethany and spent the night there.

18.text: Now early in the morning, as he returned to the city, he was hungry.

19.text: After noticing a fig tree by the road he went to it, but found nothing on it except leaves. He said to it, “Never again will there be fruit from you!” And the fig tree withered at once.

20.text: When the disciples saw it they were amazed, saying, “How did the fig tree wither so quickly?”

21.text: Jesus answered them, “I tell you the truth, if you have faith and do not doubt, not only will you do what was done to the fig tree, but even if you say to this mountain, ‘Be lifted up and thrown into the sea,’ it will happen.

22.text: And whatever you ask in prayer, if you believe, you will receive.”

23.text: Now after Jesus entered the temple courts, the chief priests and elders of the people came up to him as he was teaching and said, “By what authority are you doing these things, and who gave you this authority?”

24.text: Jesus answered them, “I will also ask you one question. If you answer me then I will also tell you by what authority I do these things.

25.text: Where did John’s baptism come from? From heaven or from people?” They discussed this among themselves, saying, “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ he will say, ‘Then why did you not believe him?’

26.text: But if we say, ‘From people,’ we fear the crowd, for they all consider John to be a prophet.”

27.text: So they answered Jesus, “We don’t know.” Then he said to them, “Neither will I tell you by what authority I am doing these things.

28.text: “What do you think? A man had two sons. He went to the first and said, ‘Son, go and work in the vineyard today.’

29.text: The boy answered, ‘I will not.’ But later he had a change of heart and went.

30.text: The father went to the other son and said the same thing. This boy answered, ‘I will, sir,’ but did not go.

31.text: Which of the two did his father’s will?” They said, “The first.” Jesus said to them, “I tell you the truth, tax collectors and prostitutes will go ahead of you into the kingdom of God!

32.text: For John came to you in the way of righteousness, and you did not believe him. But the tax collectors and prostitutes did believe. Although you saw this, you did not later change your minds and believe him.

33.text: “Listen to another parable: There was a landowner who planted a vineyard. He put a fence around it, dug a pit for its winepress, and built a watchtower. Then he leased it to tenant farmers and went on a journey.

34.text: When the harvest time was near, he sent his slaves to the tenants to collect his portion of the crop.

35.text: But the tenants seized his slaves, beat one, killed another, and stoned another.

36.text: Again he sent other slaves, more than the first, and they treated them the same way.

37.text: Finally he sent his son to them, saying, ‘They will respect my son.’

38.text: But when the tenants saw the son, they said to themselves, ‘This is the heir. Come, let’s kill him and get his inheritance!’

39.text: So they seized him, threw him out of the vineyard, and killed him.

40.text: Now when the owner of the vineyard comes, what will he do to those tenants?”

41.text: They said to him, “He will utterly destroy those evil men! Then he will lease the vineyard to other tenants who will give him his portion at the harvest.”

42.text: Jesus said to them, “Have you never read in the scriptures: ‘The stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone. This is from the Lord, and it is marvelous in our eyes’?

43.text: For this reason I tell you that the kingdom of God will be taken from you and given to a people who will produce its fruit.

44.text: The one who falls on this stone will be broken to pieces, and the one on whom it falls will be crushed.”

45.text: When the chief priests and the Pharisees heard his parables, they realized that he was speaking about them.

46.text: They wanted to arrest him, but they were afraid of the crowds, because the crowds regarded him as a prophet.

1.text: Now after the Sabbath, at dawn on the first day of the week, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary went to look at the tomb.

2.text: Suddenly there was a severe earthquake, for an angel of the Lord descending from heaven came and rolled away the stone and sat on it.

3.text: His appearance was like lightning, and his clothes were white as snow.

4.text: The guards were shaken and became like dead men because they were so afraid of him.

5.text: But the angel said to the women, “Do not be afraid; I know that you are looking for Jesus, who was crucified.

6.text: He is not here, for he has been raised, just as he said. Come and see the place where he was lying.

7.text: Then go quickly and tell his disciples, ‘He has been raised from the dead. He is going ahead of you into Galilee. You will see him there.’ Listen, I have told you!”

8.text: So they left the tomb quickly, with fear and great joy, and ran to tell his disciples.

9.text: But Jesus met them, saying, “Greetings!” They came to him, held on to his feet and worshiped him.

10.text: Then Jesus said to them, “Do not be afraid. Go and tell my brothers to go to Galilee. They will see me there.”

11.text: While they were going, some of the guard went into the city and told the chief priests everything that had happened.

12.text: After they had assembled with the elders and formed a plan, they gave a large sum of money to the soldiers,

13.text: telling them, “You are to say, ‘His disciples came at night and stole his body while we were asleep.’

14.text: If this matter is heard before the governor, we will satisfy him and keep you out of trouble.”

15.text: So they took the money and did as they were instructed. And this story is told among the Jews to this day.

16.text: So the eleven disciples went to Galilee to the mountain Jesus had designated.

17.text: When they saw him, they worshiped him, but some doubted.

18.text: Then Jesus came up and said to them, “All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me.

19.text: Therefore go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit,

20.text: teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you. And remember, I am with you always, to the end of the age.”

1.text: I wrote the former account, Theophilus, about all that Jesus began to do and teach

2.text: until the day he was taken up to heaven, after he had given orders by the Holy Spirit to the apostles he had chosen.

3.text: To the same apostles also, after his suffering, he presented himself alive with many convincing proofs. He was seen by them over a forty-day period and spoke about matters concerning the kingdom of God.

4.text: While he was with them, he declared, “Do not leave Jerusalem, but wait there for what my Father promised, which you heard about from me.

5.text: For John baptized with water, but you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit not many days from now.”

6.text: So when they had gathered together, they began to ask him, “Lord, is this the time when you are restoring the kingdom to Israel?”

7.text: He told them, “You are not permitted to know the times or periods that the Father has set by his own authority.

8.text: But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit has come upon you, and you will be my witnesses in Jerusalem, and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the farthest parts of the earth.”

9.text: After he had said this, while they were watching, he was lifted up and a cloud hid him from their sight.

10.text: As they were still staring into the sky while he was going, suddenly two men in white clothing stood near them

11.text: and said, “Men of Galilee, why do you stand here looking up into the sky? This same Jesus who has been taken up from you into heaven will come back in the same way you saw him go into heaven.”

12.text: Then they returned to Jerusalem from the mountain called the Mount of Olives (which is near Jerusalem, a Sabbath day’s journey away).

13.text: When they had entered Jerusalem, they went to the upstairs room where they were staying. Peter and John, and James, and Andrew, Philip and Thomas, Bartholomew and Matthew, James son of Alphaeus and Simon the Zealot, and Judas son of James were there.

14.text: All these continued together in prayer with one mind, together with the women, along with Mary the mother of Jesus, and his brothers.

15.text: In those days Peter stood up among the believers (a gathering of about one hundred and twenty people) and said,

16.text: “Brothers, the scripture had to be fulfilled that the Holy Spirit foretold through David concerning Judas – who became the guide for those who arrested Jesus –

17.text: for he was counted as one of us and received a share in this ministry.”

18.text: (Now this man Judas acquired a field with the reward of his unjust deed, and falling headfirst he burst open in the middle and all his intestines gushed out.

19.text: This became known to all who lived in Jerusalem, so that in their own language they called that field Hakeldama, that is, “Field of Blood.”)

20.text: “For it is written in the book of Psalms, ‘Let his house become deserted, and let there be no one to live in it,’ and ‘Let another take his position of responsibility.’

21.text: Thus one of the men who have accompanied us during all the time the Lord Jesus associated with us,

22.text: beginning from his baptism by John until the day he was taken up from us – one of these must become a witness of his resurrection together with us.”

23.text: So they proposed two candidates: Joseph called Barsabbas (also called Justus) and Matthias.

24.text: Then they prayed, “Lord, you know the hearts of all. Show us which one of these two you have chosen

25.text: to assume the task of this service and apostleship from which Judas turned aside to go to his own place.”

26.text: Then they cast lots for them, and the one chosen was Matthias; so he was counted with the eleven apostles.

1.text: Now when the day of Pentecost had come, they were all together in one place.

2.text: Suddenly a sound like a violent wind blowing came from heaven and filled the entire house where they were sitting.

3.text: And tongues spreading out like a fire appeared to them and came to rest on each one of them.

4.text: All of them were filled with the Holy Spirit, and they began to speak in other languages as the Spirit enabled them.

5.text: Now there were devout Jews from every nation under heaven residing in Jerusalem.

6.text: When this sound occurred, a crowd gathered and was in confusion, because each one heard them speaking in his own language.

7.text: Completely baffled, they said, “Aren’t all these who are speaking Galileans?

8.text: And how is it that each one of us hears them in our own native language?

9.text: Parthians, Medes, Elamites, and residents of Mesopotamia, Judea and Cappadocia, Pontus and the province of Asia,

10.text: Phrygia and Pamphylia, Egypt and the parts of Libya near Cyrene, and visitors from Rome,

11.text: both Jews and proselytes, Cretans and Arabs – we hear them speaking in our own languages about the great deeds God has done!”

12.text: All were astounded and greatly confused, saying to one another, “What does this mean?”

13.text: But others jeered at the speakers, saying, “They are drunk on new wine!”

14.text: But Peter stood up with the eleven, raised his voice, and addressed them: “You men of Judea and all you who live in Jerusalem, know this and listen carefully to what I say.

15.text: In spite of what you think, these men are not drunk, for it is only nine o’clock in the morning.

16.text: But this is what was spoken about through the prophet Joel:

17.text: ‘And in the last days it will be,’ God says, ‘that I will pour out my Spirit on all people, and your sons and your daughters will prophesy, and your young men will see visions, and your old men will dream dreams.

18.text: Even on my servants, both men and women,* I will pour out my Spirit in those days, and they will prophesy.

19.text: And I will perform wonders in the sky above* and miraculous signs on the earth below, blood and fire and clouds of smoke.

20.text: The sun will be changed to darkness and the moon to blood before the great and glorious day of the Lord comes.

21.text: And then everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.’

22.text: “Men of Israel, listen to these words: Jesus the Nazarene, a man clearly attested to you by God with powerful deeds, wonders, and miraculous signs that God performed among you through him, just as you yourselves know –

23.text: this man, who was handed over by the predetermined plan and foreknowledge of God, you executed by nailing him to a cross at the hands of Gentiles.

24.text: But God raised him up, having released him from the pains of death, because it was not possible for him to be held in its power.

25.text: For David says about him, ‘I saw the Lord always in front of me, for he is at my right hand so that I will not be shaken.

26.text: Therefore my heart was glad and my tongue rejoiced; my body also will live in hope,

27.text: because you will not leave my soul in Hades, nor permit your Holy One to experience decay.

28.text: You have made known to me the paths of life; you will make me full of joy with your presence.’

29.text: “Brothers, I can speak confidently to you about our forefather David, that he both died and was buried, and his tomb is with us to this day.

30.text: So then, because he was a prophet and knew that God had sworn to him with an oath to seat one of his descendants on his throne,

31.text: David by foreseeing this spoke about the resurrection of the Christ, that he was neither abandoned to Hades, nor did his body experience decay.

32.text: This Jesus God raised up, and we are all witnesses of it.

33.text: So then, exalted to the right hand of God, and having received the promise of the Holy Spirit from the Father, he has poured out what you both see and hear.

34.text: For David did not ascend into heaven, but he himself says, ‘The Lord said to my lord, “Sit at my right hand*

35.text: until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet.”’

36.text: Therefore let all the house of Israel know beyond a doubt that God has made this Jesus whom you crucified both Lord and Christ.”

37.text: Now when they heard this, they were acutely distressed and said to Peter and the rest of the apostles, “What should we do, brothers?”

38.text: Peter said to them, “Repent, and each one of you be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit.

39.text: For the promise is for you and your children, and for all who are far away, as many as the Lord our God will call to himself.”

40.text: With many other words he testified and exhorted them saying, “Save yourselves from this perverse generation!”

41.text: So those who accepted his message were baptized, and that day about three thousand people were added.

42.text: They were devoting themselves to the apostles’ teaching and to fellowship, to the breaking of bread and to prayer.

43.text: Reverential awe came over everyone, and many wonders and miraculous signs came about by the apostles.

44.text: All who believed were together and held everything in common,

45.text: and they began selling their property and possessions and distributing the proceeds to everyone, as anyone had need.

46.text: Every day they continued to gather together by common consent in the temple courts, breaking bread from house to house, sharing their food with glad and humble hearts,

47.text: praising God and having the good will of all the people. And the Lord was adding to their number every day those who were being saved.

1.text: Now Peter and John were going up to the temple at the time for prayer, at three o’clock in the afternoon.

2.text: And a man lame from birth was being carried up, who was placed at the temple gate called “the Beautiful Gate” every day so he could beg for money from those going into the temple courts.

3.text: When he saw Peter and John about to go into the temple courts, he asked them for money.

4.text: Peter looked directly at him (as did John) and said, “Look at us!”

5.text: So the lame man paid attention to them, expecting to receive something from them.

6.text: But Peter said, “I have no silver or gold, but what I do have I give you. In the name of Jesus Christ the Nazarene, stand up and walk!”

7.text: Then Peter took hold of him by the right hand and raised him up, and at once the man’s feet and ankles were made strong.

8.text: He jumped up, stood and began walking around, and he entered the temple courts with them, walking and leaping and praising God.

9.text: All the people saw him walking and praising God,

10.text: and they recognized him as the man who used to sit and ask for donations at the Beautiful Gate of the temple, and they were filled with astonishment and amazement at what had happened to him.

11.text: While the man was hanging on to Peter and John, all the people, completely astounded, ran together to them in the covered walkway called Solomon’s Portico.

12.text: When Peter saw this, he declared to the people, “Men of Israel, why are you amazed at this? Why do you stare at us as if we had made this man walk by our own power or piety?

13.text: The God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, the God of our forefathers, has glorified his servant Jesus, whom you handed over and rejected in the presence of Pilate after he had decided to release him.

14.text: But you rejected the Holy and Righteous One and asked that a man who was a murderer be released to you.

15.text: You killed the Originator of life, whom God raised from the dead. To this fact we are witnesses!

16.text: And on the basis of faith in Jesus’ name, his very name has made this man – whom you see and know – strong. The faith that is through Jesus has given him this complete health in the presence of you all.

17.text: And now, brothers, I know you acted in ignorance, as your rulers did too.

18.text: But the things God foretold long ago through all the prophets – that his Christ would suffer – he has fulfilled in this way.

19.text: Therefore repent and turn back so that your sins may be wiped out,

20.text: so that times of refreshing may come from the presence of the Lord, and so that he may send the Messiah appointed for you – that is, Jesus.

21.text: This one heaven must receive until the time all things are restored, which God declared from times long ago through his holy prophets.

22.text: Moses said, ‘The Lord your God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among your brothers. You must obey him in everything he tells you*.

23.text: Every person who does not obey that prophet will be destroyed and thus removed from the people.’

24.text: And all the prophets, from Samuel and those who followed him, have spoken about and announced these days.

25.text: You are the sons of the prophets and of the covenant that God made with your ancestors, saying to Abraham, ‘And in your descendants all the nations of the earth will be blessed: *.’

26.text: God raised up his servant and sent him first to you, to bless you by turning each one of you from your iniquities.”

1.text: While Peter and John were speaking to the people, the priests and the commander of the temple guard and the Sadducees came up to them,

2.text: angry because they were teaching the people and announcing in Jesus the resurrection of the dead.

3.text: So they seized them and put them in jail until the next day (for it was already evening).

4.text: But many of those who had listened to the message believed, and the number of the men came to about five thousand.

5.text: On the next day, their rulers, elders, and experts in the law came together in Jerusalem.

6.text: Annas the high priest was there, and Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and others who were members of the high priest’s family.

7.text: After making Peter and John stand in their midst, they began to inquire, “By what power or by what name did you do this?”

8.text: Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, replied, “Rulers of the people and elders,

9.text: if we are being examined today for a good deed done to a sick man – by what means this man was healed –

10.text: let it be known to all of you and to all the people of Israel that by the name of Jesus Christ the Nazarene whom you crucified, whom God raised from the dead, this man stands before you healthy.

11.text: This Jesus is the stone that was rejected by that was rejected by you, the builders, that has become the cornerstone.

12.text: And there is salvation in no one else, for there is no other name under heaven given among people by which we must be saved.”

13.text: When they saw the boldness of Peter and John, and discovered that they were uneducated and ordinary men, they were amazed and recognized these men had been with Jesus.

14.text: And because they saw the man who had been healed standing with them, they had nothing to say against this.

15.text: But when they had ordered them to go outside the council, they began to confer with one another,

16.text: saying, “What should we do with these men? For it is plain to all who live in Jerusalem that a notable miraculous sign has come about through them, and we cannot deny it.

17.text: But to keep this matter from spreading any further among the people, let us warn them to speak no more to anyone in this name.”

18.text: And they called them in and ordered them not to speak or teach at all in the name of Jesus.

19.text: But Peter and John replied, “Whether it is right before God to obey you rather than God, you decide,

20.text: for it is impossible for us not to speak about what we have seen and heard.”

21.text: After threatening them further, they released them, for they could not find how to punish them on account of the people, because they were all praising God for what had happened.

22.text: For the man, on whom this miraculous sign of healing had been performed, was over forty years old.

23.text: When they were released, Peter and John went to their fellow believers and reported everything the high priests and the elders had said to them.

24.text: When they heard this, they raised their voices to God with one mind and said, “Master of all, you who made the heaven, the earth, the sea, and everything that is in them,

25.text: who said by the Holy Spirit through your servant David our forefather, ‘Why do the nations rage, and the peoples plot foolish things?

26.text: The kings of the earth stood together, and the rulers assembled together, against the Lord and against his Christ: *.’

27.text: “For indeed both Herod and Pontius Pilate, with the Gentiles and the people of Israel, assembled together in this city against your holy servant Jesus, whom you anointed,

28.text: to do as much as your power and your plan had decided beforehand would happen.

29.text: And now, Lord, pay attention to their threats, and grant to your servants to speak your message with great courage,

30.text: while you extend your hand to heal, and to bring about miraculous signs and wonders through the name of your holy servant Jesus.”

31.text: When they had prayed, the place where they were assembled together was shaken, and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak the word of God courageously.

32.text: The group of those who believed were of one heart and mind, and no one said that any of his possessions was his own, but everything was held in common.

33.text: With great power the apostles were giving testimony to the resurrection of the Lord Jesus, and great grace was on them all.

34.text: For there was no one needy among them, because those who were owners of land or houses were selling them and bringing the proceeds from the sales

35.text: and placing them at the apostles’ feet. The proceeds were distributed to each, as anyone had need.

36.text: So Joseph, a Levite who was a native of Cyprus, called by the apostles Barnabas (which is translated “son of encouragement”),

37.text: sold a field that belonged to him and brought the money and placed it at the apostles’ feet.

1.text: After they traveled through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a Jewish synagogue.

2.text: Paul went to the Jews in the synagogue, as he customarily did, and on three Sabbath days he addressed them from the scriptures,

3.text: explaining and demonstrating that the Christ had to suffer and to rise from the dead, saying, “This Jesus I am proclaiming to you is the Christ.”

4.text: Some of them were persuaded and joined Paul and Silas, along with a large group of God-fearing Greeks and quite a few prominent women.

5.text: But the Jews became jealous, and gathering together some worthless men from the rabble in the marketplace, they formed a mob and set the city in an uproar. They attacked Jason’s house, trying to find Paul and Silas to bring them out to the assembly.

6.text: When they did not find them, they dragged Jason and some of the brothers before the city officials, screaming, “These people who have stirred up trouble throughout the world have come here too,

7.text: and Jason has welcomed them as guests! They are all acting against Caesar’s decrees, saying there is another king named Jesus!”

8.text: They caused confusion among the crowd and the city officials who heard these things.

9.text: After the city officials had received bail from Jason and the others, they released them.

10.text: The brothers sent Paul and Silas off to Berea at once, during the night. When they arrived, they went to the Jewish synagogue.

11.text: These Jews were more open-minded than those in Thessalonica, for they eagerly received the message, examining the scriptures carefully every day to see if these things were so.

12.text: Therefore many of them believed, along with quite a few prominent Greek women and men.

13.text: But when the Jews from Thessalonica heard that Paul had also proclaimed the word of God in Berea, they came there too, inciting and disturbing the crowds.

14.text: Then the brothers sent Paul away to the coast at once, but Silas and Timothy remained in Berea.

15.text: Those who accompanied Paul escorted him as far as Athens, and after receiving an order for Silas and Timothy to come to him as soon as possible, they left.

16.text: While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, his spirit was greatly upset because he saw the city was full of idols.

17.text: So he was addressing the Jews and the God-fearing Gentiles in the synagogue, and in the marketplace every day those who happened to be there.

18.text: Also some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers were conversing with him, and some were asking, “What does this foolish babbler want to say?” Others said, “He seems to be a proclaimer of foreign gods.” (They said this because he was proclaiming the good news about Jesus and the resurrection.)

19.text: So they took Paul and brought him to the Areopagus, saying, “May we know what this new teaching is that you are proclaiming?

20.text: For you are bringing some surprising things to our ears, so we want to know what they mean.”

21.text: (All the Athenians and the foreigners who lived there used to spend their time in nothing else than telling or listening to something new.)

22.text: So Paul stood before the Areopagus and said, “Men of Athens, I see that you are very religious in all respects.

23.text: For as I went around and observed closely your objects of worship, I even found an altar with this inscription: ‘To an unknown god.’ Therefore what you worship without knowing it, this I proclaim to you.

24.text: The God who made the world and everything in it, who is Lord of heaven and earth, does not live in temples made by human hands,

25.text: nor is he served by human hands, as if he needed anything, because he himself gives life and breath and everything to everyone.

26.text: From one man he made every nation of the human race to inhabit the entire earth, determining their set times and the fixed limits of the places where they would live,

27.text: so that they would search for God and perhaps grope around for him and find him, though he is not far from each one of us.

28.text: For in him we live and move about and exist, as even some of your own poets have said, ‘For we too are his offspring.’

29.text: So since we are God’s offspring, we should not think the deity is like gold or silver or stone, an image made by human skill and imagination.

30.text: Therefore, although God has overlooked such times of ignorance, he now commands all people everywhere to repent,

31.text: because he has set a day on which he is going to judge the world in righteousness, by a man whom he designated, having provided proof to everyone by raising him from the dead.”

32.text: Now when they heard about the resurrection from the dead, some began to scoff, but others said, “We will hear you again about this.”

33.text: So Paul left the Areopagus.

34.text: But some people joined him and believed. Among them were Dionysius, who was a member of the Areopagus, a woman named Damaris, and others with them.

1.text: Now in those days a decree went out from Caesar Augustus to register all the empire for taxes.

2.text: This was the first registration, taken when Quirinius was governor of Syria.

3.text: Everyone went to his own town to be registered.

4.text: So Joseph also went up from the town of Nazareth because he was of the house and family line of David.

5.text: He went to be registered with Mary, who was promised in marriage to him, and who was expecting a child.

6.text: While they were there, the time came for her to deliver her child.

7.text: And she gave birth to her firstborn son and wrapped him in strips of cloth and laid him in a manger, because there was no place for them in the inn.

8.text: Now there were shepherds nearby living out in the field, keeping guard over their flock at night.

9.text: An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were absolutely terrified.

10.text: But the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid! Listen carefully, for I proclaim to you good news that brings great joy to all the people:

11.text: Today your Savior is born in the city of David. He is Christ the Lord.

12.text: This will be a sign for you: You will find a baby wrapped in strips of cloth and lying in a manger.”

13.text: Suddenly a vast, heavenly army appeared with the angel, praising God and saying,

14.text: “Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace among people with whom he is pleased!”

15.text: When the angels left them and went back to heaven, the shepherds said to one another, “Let us go over to Bethlehem and see this thing that has taken place, that the Lord has made known to us.”

16.text: So they hurried off and located Mary and Joseph, and found the baby lying in a manger.

17.text: When they saw him, they related what they had been told about this child,

18.text: and all who heard it were astonished at what the shepherds said.

19.text: But Mary treasured up all these words, pondering in her heart what they might mean.

20.text: So the shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all they had heard and seen; everything was just as they had been told.

21.text: At the end of eight days, when he was circumcised, he was named Jesus, the name given by the angel before he was conceived in the womb.

22.text: Now when the time came for their purification according to the law of Moses, Joseph and Mary brought Jesus up to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord

23.text: (just as it is written in the law of the Lord, “Every firstborn male will be set apart to the Lord” ),

24.text: and to offer a sacrifice according to what is specified in the law of the Lord, a pair of doves of doves or two young pigeons.

25.text: Now there was a man in Jerusalem named Simeon who was righteous and devout, looking for the restoration of Israel, and the Holy Spirit was upon him.

26.text: It had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit that he would not die before he had seen the Lord’s Christ.

27.text: So Simeon, directed by the Spirit, came into the temple courts, and when the parents brought in the child Jesus to do for him what was customary according to the law,

28.text: Simeon took him in his arms and blessed God, saying,

29.text: “Now, according to your word, Sovereign Lord, permit your servant to depart in peace.

30.text: For my eyes have seen your salvation

31.text: that you have prepared in the presence of all peoples:

32.text: a light, for revelation to the Gentiles, and for glory to your people Israel.”

33.text: So the child’s father and mother were amazed at what was said about him.

34.text: Then Simeon blessed them and said to his mother Mary, “Listen carefully: This child is destined to be the cause of the falling and rising of many in Israel and to be a sign that will be rejected.

35.text: Indeed, as a result of him the thoughts of many hearts will be revealed – and a sword will pierce your own soul as well!”

36.text: There was also a prophetess, Anna the daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Asher. She was very old, having been married to her husband for seven years until his death.

37.text: She had lived as a widow since then for eighty-four years. She never left the temple, worshiping with fasting and prayer night and day.

38.text: At that moment, she came up to them and began to give thanks to God and to speak about the child to all who were waiting for the redemption of Jerusalem.

39.text: So when Joseph and Mary had performed everything according to the law of the Lord, they returned to Galilee, to their own town of Nazareth.

40.text: And the child grew and became strong, filled with wisdom, and the favor of God was upon him.

41.text: Now Jesus’ parents went to Jerusalem every year for the feast of the Passover.

42.text: When he was twelve years old, they went up according to custom.

43.text: But when the feast was over, as they were returning home, the boy Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem. His parents did not know it,

44.text: but (because they assumed that he was in their group of travelers) they went a day’s journey. Then they began to look for him among their relatives and acquaintances.

45.text: When they did not find him, they returned to Jerusalem to look for him.

46.text: After three days they found him in the temple courts, sitting among the teachers, listening to them and asking them questions.

47.text: And all who heard Jesus were astonished at his understanding and his answers.

48.text: When his parents saw him, they were overwhelmed. His mother said to him, “Child, why have you treated us like this? Look, your father and I have been looking for you anxiously.”

49.text: But he replied, “Why were you looking for me? Didn’t you know that I must be in my Father’s house?”

50.text: Yet his parents did not understand the remark he made to them.

51.text: Then he went down with them and came to Nazareth, and was obedient to them. But his mother kept all these things in her heart.

52.text: And Jesus increased in wisdom and in stature, and in favor with God and with people.

1.text: Jesus was going through the grain fields on a Sabbath, and his disciples picked some heads of wheat, rubbed them in their hands, and ate them.

2.text: But some of the Pharisees said, “Why are you doing what is against the law on the Sabbath?”

3.text: Jesus answered them, “Haven’t you read what David did when he and his companions were hungry –

4.text: how he entered the house of God, took and ate the sacred bread, which is not lawful for any to eat but the priests alone, and gave it to his companions?”

5.text: Then he said to them, “The Son of Man is lord of the Sabbath.”

6.text: On another Sabbath, Jesus entered the synagogue and was teaching. Now a man was there whose right hand was withered.

7.text: The experts in the law and the Pharisees watched Jesus closely to see if he would heal on the Sabbath, so that they could find a reason to accuse him.

8.text: But he knew their thoughts, and said to the man who had the withered hand, “Get up and stand here.” So he rose and stood there.

9.text: Then Jesus said to them, “I ask you, is it lawful to do good on the Sabbath or to do evil, to save a life or to destroy it?”

10.text: After looking around at them all, he said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” The man did so, and his hand was restored.

11.text: But they were filled with mindless rage and began debating with one another what they would do to Jesus.

12.text: Now it was during this time that Jesus went out to the mountain to pray, and he spent all night in prayer to God.

13.text: When morning came, he called his disciples and chose twelve of them, whom he also named apostles:

14.text: Simon (whom he named Peter), and his brother Andrew; and James, John, Philip, Bartholomew,

15.text: Matthew, Thomas, James the son of Alphaeus, Simon who was called the Zealot,

16.text: Judas the son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who became a traitor.

17.text: Then he came down with them and stood on a level place. And a large number of his disciples had gathered along with a vast multitude from all over Judea, from Jerusalem, They came to hear him and to be healed of their diseases,

18.text: and those who suffered from unclean spirits were cured.

19.text: The whole crowd was trying to touch him, because power was coming out from him and healing them all.

20.text: Then he looked up at his disciples and said: “Blessed are you who are poor, for the kingdom of God belongs to you.

21.text: “Blessed are you who hunger now, for you will be satisfied. “Blessed are you who weep now, for you will laugh.

22.text: “Blessed are you when people hate you, and when they exclude you and insult you and reject you as evil on account of the Son of Man!

23.text: Rejoice in that day, and jump for joy, because your reward is great in heaven. For their ancestors did the same things to the prophets.

24.text: “But woe to you who are rich, for you have received your comfort already.

25.text: “Woe to you who are well satisfied with food now, for you will be hungry. “Woe to you who laugh now, for you will mourn and weep.

26.text: “Woe to you when all people speak well of you, for their ancestors did the same things to the false prophets.

27.text: “But I say to you who are listening: Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you,

28.text: bless those who curse you, pray for those who mistreat you.

29.text: To the person who strikes you on the cheek, offer the other as well, and from the person who takes away your coat, do not withhold your tunic either.

30.text: Give to everyone who asks you, and do not ask for your possessions back from the person who takes them away.

31.text: Treat others in the same way that you would want them to treat you.

32.text: “If you love those who love you, what credit is that to you? For even sinners love those who love them.

33.text: And if you do good to those who do good to you, what credit is that to you? Even sinners do the same.

34.text: And if you lend to those from whom you hope to be repaid, what credit is that to you? Even sinners lend to sinners, so that they may be repaid in full.

35.text: But love your enemies, and do good, and lend, expecting nothing back. Then your reward will be great, and you will be sons of the Most High, because he is kind to ungrateful and evil people.

36.text: Be merciful, just as your Father is merciful.

37.text: “Do not judge, and you will not be judged; do not condemn, and you will not be condemned; forgive, and you will be forgiven.

38.text: Give, and it will be given to you: A good measure, pressed down, shaken together, running over, will be poured into your lap. For the measure you use will be the measure you receive.”

39.text: He also told them a parable: “Someone who is blind cannot lead another who is blind, can he? Won’t they both fall into a pit?

40.text: A disciple is not greater than his teacher, but everyone when fully trained will be like his teacher.

41.text: Why do you see the speck in your brother’s eye, but fail to see the beam of wood in your own?

42.text: How can you say to your brother, ‘Brother, let me remove the speck from your eye,’ while you yourself don’t see the beam in your own? You hypocrite! First remove the beam from your own eye, and then you can see clearly to remove the speck from your brother’s eye.

43.text: “For no good tree bears bad fruit, nor again does a bad tree bear good fruit,

44.text: for each tree is known by its own fruit. For figs are not gathered from thorns, nor are grapes picked from brambles.

45.text: The good person out of the good treasury of his heart produces good, and the evil person out of his evil treasury produces evil, for his mouth speaks from what fills his heart.

46.text: “Why do you call me ‘Lord, Lord,’ and don’t do what I tell you?

47.text: “Everyone who comes to me and listens to my words and puts them into practice – I will show you what he is like:

48.text: He is like a man building a house, who dug down deep, and laid the foundation on bedrock. When a flood came, the river burst against that house but could not shake it, because it had been well built.

49.text: But the person who hears and does not put my words into practice is like a man who built a house on the ground without a foundation. When the river burst against that house, it collapsed immediately, and was utterly destroyed!”

1.text: After Jesus called the twelve together, he gave them power and authority over all demons and to cure diseases,

2.text: and he sent them out to proclaim the kingdom of God and to heal the sick.

3.text: He said to them, “Take nothing for your journey – no staff, no bag, no bread, no money, and do not take an extra tunic.

4.text: Whatever house you enter, stay there until you leave the area.

5.text: Wherever they do not receive you, as you leave that town, shake the dust off your feet as a testimony against them.”

6.text: Then they departed and went throughout the villages, proclaiming the good news and healing people everywhere.

7.text: Now Herod the tetrarch heard about everything that was happening, and he was thoroughly perplexed, because some people were saying that John had been raised from the dead,

8.text: while others were saying that Elijah had appeared, and still others that one of the prophets of long ago had risen.

9.text: Herod said, “I had John beheaded, but who is this about whom I hear such things?” So Herod wanted to learn about Jesus.

10.text: When the apostles returned, they told Jesus everything they had done. Then he took them with him and they withdrew privately to a town called Bethsaida.

11.text: But when the crowds found out, they followed him. He welcomed them, spoke to them about the kingdom of God, and cured those who needed healing.

12.text: Now the day began to draw to a close, so the twelve came and said to Jesus, “Send the crowd away, so they can go into the surrounding villages and countryside and find lodging and food, because we are in an isolated place.”

13.text: But he said to them, “You give them something to eat.” They replied, “We have no more than five loaves and two fish – unless we go and buy food for all these people.”

14.text: (Now about five thousand men were there.) Then he said to his disciples, “Have them sit down in groups of about fifty each.”

15.text: So they did as Jesus directed, and the people all sat down.

16.text: Then he took the five loaves and the two fish, and looking up to heaven he gave thanks and broke them. He gave them to the disciples to set before the crowd.

17.text: They all ate and were satisfied, and what was left over was picked up – twelve baskets of broken pieces.

18.text: Once when Jesus was praying by himself, and his disciples were nearby, he asked them, “Who do the crowds say that I am?”

19.text: They answered, “John the Baptist; others say Elijah; and still others that one of the prophets of long ago has risen.”

20.text: Then he said to them, “But who do you say that I am?” Peter answered, “The Christ of God.”

21.text: But he forcefully commanded them not to tell this to anyone,

22.text: saying, “The Son of Man must suffer many things and be rejected by the elders, chief priests, and experts in the law, and be killed, and on the third day be raised.”

23.text: Then he said to them all, “If anyone wants to become my follower, he must deny himself, take up his cross daily, and follow me.

24.text: For whoever wants to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for my sake will save it.

25.text: For what does it benefit a person if he gains the whole world but loses or forfeits himself?

26.text: For whoever is ashamed of me and my words, the Son of Man will be ashamed of that person when he comes in his glory and in the glory of the Father and of the holy angels.

27.text: But I tell you most certainly, there are some standing here who will not experience death before they see the kingdom of God.”

28.text: Now about eight days after these sayings, Jesus took with him Peter, John, and James, and went up the mountain to pray.

29.text: As he was praying, the appearance of his face was transformed, and his clothes became very bright, a brilliant white.

30.text: Then two men, Moses and Elijah, began talking with him.

31.text: They appeared in glorious splendor and spoke about his departure that he was about to carry out at Jerusalem.

32.text: Now Peter and those with him were quite sleepy, but as they became fully awake, they saw his glory and the two men standing with him.

33.text: Then as the men were starting to leave, Peter said to Jesus, “Master, it is good for us to be here. Let us make three shelters, one for you and one for Moses and one for Elijah” – not knowing what he was saying.

34.text: As he was saying this, a cloud came and overshadowed them, and they were afraid as they entered the cloud.

35.text: Then a voice came from the cloud, saying, “This is my Son, my Chosen One. Listen to him!”

36.text: After the voice had spoken, Jesus was found alone. So they kept silent and told no one at that time anything of what they had seen.

37.text: Now on the next day, when they had come down from the mountain, a large crowd met him.

38.text: Then a man from the crowd cried out, “Teacher, I beg you to look at my son – he is my only child!

39.text: A spirit seizes him, and he suddenly screams; it throws him into convulsions and causes him to foam at the mouth. It hardly ever leaves him alone, torturing him severely.

40.text: I begged your disciples to cast it out, but they could not do so.”

41.text: Jesus answered, “You unbelieving and perverse generation! How much longer must I be with you and endure you? Bring your son here.”

42.text: As the boy was approaching, the demon threw him to the ground and shook him with convulsions. But Jesus rebuked the unclean spirit, healed the boy, and gave him back to his father.

43.text: Then they were all astonished at the mighty power of God. Another Prediction of Jesus’ Suffering But while the entire crowd was amazed at everything Jesus was doing, he said to his disciples,

44.text: “Take these words to heart, for the Son of Man is going to be betrayed into the hands of men.”

45.text: But they did not understand this statement; its meaning had been concealed from them, so that they could not grasp it. Yet they were afraid to ask him about this statement.

46.text: Now an argument started among the disciples as to which of them might be the greatest.

47.text: But when Jesus discerned their innermost thoughts, he took a child, had him stand by his side,

48.text: and said to them, “Whoever welcomes this child in my name welcomes me, and whoever welcomes me welcomes the one who sent me, for the one who is least among you all is the one who is great.”

49.text: John answered, “Master, we saw someone casting out demons in your name, and we tried to stop him because he is not a disciple along with us.”

50.text: But Jesus said to him, “Do not stop him, for whoever is not against you is for you.”

51.text: Now when the days drew near for him to be taken up, Jesus set out resolutely to go to Jerusalem.

52.text: He sent messengers on ahead of him. As they went along, they entered a Samaritan village to make things ready in advance for him,

53.text: but the villagers refused to welcome him, because he was determined to go to Jerusalem.

54.text: Now when his disciples James and John saw this, they said, “Lord, do you want us to call fire to come down from heaven and consume them?”

55.text: But Jesus turned and rebuked them,

56.text: and they went on to another village.

57.text: As they were walking along the road, someone said to him, “I will follow you wherever you go.”

58.text: Jesus said to him, “Foxes have dens and the birds in the sky have nests, but the Son of Man has no place to lay his head.”

59.text: Jesus said to another, “Follow me.” But he replied, “Lord, first let me go and bury my father.”

60.text: But Jesus said to him, “Let the dead bury their own dead, but as for you, go and proclaim the kingdom of God.”

61.text: Yet another said, “I will follow you, Lord, but first let me say goodbye to my family.”

62.text: Jesus said to him, “No one who puts his hand to the plow and looks back is fit for the kingdom of God.”

1.text: Now Jesus was praying in a certain place. When he stopped, one of his disciples said to him, “Lord, teach us to pray, just as John taught his disciples.”

2.text: So he said to them, “When you pray, say: Father, may your name be honored; may your kingdom come.

3.text: Give us each day our daily bread,

4.text: and forgive us our sins, for we also forgive everyone who sins against us. And do not lead us into temptation.”

5.text: Then he said to them, “Suppose one of you has a friend, and you go to him at midnight and say to him, ‘Friend, lend me three loaves of bread,

6.text: because a friend of mine has stopped here while on a journey, and I have nothing to set before him.’

7.text: Then he will reply from inside, ‘Do not bother me. The door is already shut, and my children and I are in bed. I cannot get up and give you anything.’

8.text: I tell you, even though the man inside will not get up and give him anything because he is his friend, yet because of the first man’s sheer persistence he will get up and give him whatever he needs.

9.text: “So I tell you: Ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and the door will be opened for you.

10.text: For everyone who asks receives, and the one who seeks finds, and to the one who knocks, the door will be opened.

11.text: What father among you, if your son asks for a fish, will give him a snake instead of a fish?

12.text: Or if he asks for an egg, will give him a scorpion?

13.text: If you then, although you are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will the heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him!”

14.text: Now he was casting out a demon that was mute. When the demon had gone out, the man who had been mute began to speak, and the crowds were amazed.

15.text: But some of them said, “By the power of Beelzebul, the ruler of demons, he casts out demons.”

16.text: Others, to test him, began asking for a sign from heaven.

17.text: But Jesus, realizing their thoughts, said to them, “Every kingdom divided against itself is destroyed, and a divided household falls.

18.text: So if Satan too is divided against himself, how will his kingdom stand? I ask you this because you claim that I cast out demons by Beelzebul.

19.text: Now if I cast out demons by Beelzebul, by whom do your sons cast them out? Therefore they will be your judges.

20.text: But if I cast out demons by the finger of God, then the kingdom of God has already overtaken you.

21.text: When a strong man, fully armed, guards his own palace, his possessions are safe.

22.text: But when a stronger man attacks and conquers him, he takes away the first man’s armor on which the man relied and divides up his plunder.

23.text: Whoever is not with me is against me, and whoever does not gather with me scatters.

24.text: “When an unclean spirit goes out of a person, it passes through waterless places looking for rest but not finding any. Then it says, ‘I will return to the home I left.’

25.text: When it returns, it finds the house swept clean and put in order.

26.text: Then it goes and brings seven other spirits more evil than itself, and they go in and live there, so the last state of that person is worse than the first.”

27.text: As he said these things, a woman in the crowd spoke out to him, “Blessed is the womb that bore you and the breasts at which you nursed!”

28.text: But he replied, “Blessed rather are those who hear the word of God and obey it!”

29.text: As the crowds were increasing, Jesus began to say, “This generation is a wicked generation; it looks for a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of Jonah.

30.text: For just as Jonah became a sign to the people of Nineveh, so the Son of Man will be a sign to this generation.

31.text: The queen of the South will rise up at the judgment with the people of this generation and condemn them, because she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon – and now, something greater than Solomon is here!

32.text: The people of Nineveh will stand up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, because they repented when Jonah preached to them – and now, something greater than Jonah is here!

33.text: “No one after lighting a lamp puts it in a hidden place or under a basket, but on a lampstand, so that those who come in can see the light.

34.text: Your eye is the lamp of your body. When your eye is healthy, your whole body is full of light, but when it is diseased, your body is full of darkness.

35.text: Therefore see to it that the light in you is not darkness.

36.text: If then your whole body is full of light, with no part in the dark, it will be as full of light as when the light of a lamp shines on you.”

37.text: As he spoke, a Pharisee invited Jesus to have a meal with him, so he went in and took his place at the table.

38.text: The Pharisee was astonished when he saw that Jesus did not first wash his hands before the meal.

39.text: But the Lord said to him, “Now you Pharisees clean the outside of the cup and the plate, but inside you are full of greed and wickedness.

40.text: You fools! Didn’t the one who made the outside make the inside as well?

41.text: But give from your heart to those in need, and then everything will be clean for you.

42.text: “But woe to you Pharisees! You give a tenth of your mint, rue, and every herb, yet you neglect justice and love for God! But you should have done these things without neglecting the others.

43.text: Woe to you Pharisees! You love the best seats in the synagogues and elaborate greetings in the marketplaces!

44.text: Woe to you! You are like unmarked graves, and people walk over them without realizing it!”

45.text: One of the experts in religious law answered him, “Teacher, when you say these things you insult us too.”

46.text: But Jesus replied, “Woe to you experts in religious law as well! You load people down with burdens difficult to bear, yet you yourselves refuse to touch the burdens with even one of your fingers!

47.text: Woe to you! You build the tombs of the prophets whom your ancestors killed.

48.text: So you testify that you approve of the deeds of your ancestors, because they killed the prophets and you build their tombs!

49.text: For this reason also the wisdom of God said, ‘I will send them prophets and apostles, some of whom they will kill and persecute,’

50.text: so that this generation may be held accountable for the blood of all the prophets that has been shed since the beginning of the world,

51.text: from the blood of Abel to the blood of Zechariah, who was killed between the altar and the sanctuary. Yes, I tell you, it will be charged against this generation.

52.text: Woe to you experts in religious law! You have taken away the key to knowledge! You did not go in yourselves, and you hindered those who were going in.”

53.text: When he went out from there, the experts in the law and the Pharisees began to oppose him bitterly, and to ask him hostile questions about many things,

54.text: plotting against him, to catch him in something he might say.

1.text: Now one Sabbath when Jesus went to dine at the house of a leader of the Pharisees, they were watching him closely.

2.text: There right in front of him was a man suffering from dropsy.

3.text: So Jesus asked the experts in religious law and the Pharisees, “Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath or not?”

4.text: But they remained silent. So Jesus took hold of the man, healed him, and sent him away.

5.text: Then he said to them, “Which of you, if you have a son or an ox that has fallen into a well on a Sabbath day, will not immediately pull him out?”

6.text: But they could not reply to this.

7.text: Then when Jesus noticed how the guests chose the places of honor, he told them a parable. He said to them,

8.text: “When you are invited by someone to a wedding feast, do not take the place of honor, because a person more distinguished than you may have been invited by your host.

9.text: So the host who invited both of you will come and say to you, ‘Give this man your place.’ Then, ashamed, you will begin to move to the least important place.

10.text: But when you are invited, go and take the least important place, so that when your host approaches he will say to you, ‘Friend, move up here to a better place.’ Then you will be honored in the presence of all who share the meal with you.

11.text: For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, but the one who humbles himself will be exalted.”

12.text: He said also to the man who had invited him, “When you host a dinner or a banquet, don’t invite your friends or your brothers or your relatives or rich neighbors so you can be invited by them in return and get repaid.

13.text: But when you host an elaborate meal, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, and the blind.

14.text: Then you will be blessed, because they cannot repay you, for you will be repaid at the resurrection of the righteous.”

15.text: When one of those at the meal with Jesus heard this, he said to him, “Blessed is everyone who will feast in the kingdom of God!”

16.text: But Jesus said to him, “A man once gave a great banquet and invited many guests.

17.text: At the time for the banquet he sent his slave to tell those who had been invited, ‘Come, because everything is now ready.’

18.text: But one after another they all began to make excuses. The first said to him, ‘I have bought a field, and I must go out and see it. Please excuse me.’

19.text: Another said, ‘I have bought five yoke of oxen, and I am going out to examine them. Please excuse me.’

20.text: Another said, ‘I just got married, and I cannot come.’

21.text: So the slave came back and reported this to his master. Then the master of the household was furious and said to his slave, ‘Go out quickly to the streets and alleys of the city, and bring in the poor, the crippled, the blind, and the lame.’

22.text: Then the slave said, ‘Sir, what you instructed has been done, and there is still room.’

23.text: So the master said to his slave, ‘Go out to the highways and country roads and urge people to come in, so that my house will be filled.

24.text: For I tell you, not one of those individuals who were invited will taste my banquet!’”

25.text: Now large crowds were accompanying Jesus, and turning to them he said,

26.text: “If anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father and mother, and wife and children, and brothers and sisters, and even his own life, he cannot be my disciple.

27.text: Whoever does not carry his own cross and follow me cannot be my disciple.

28.text: For which of you, wanting to build a tower, doesn’t sit down first and compute the cost to see if he has enough money to complete it?

29.text: Otherwise, when he has laid a foundation and is not able to finish the tower, all who see it will begin to make fun of him.

30.text: They will say, ‘This man began to build and was not able to finish!’

31.text: Or what king, going out to confront another king in battle, will not sit down first and determine whether he is able with ten thousand to oppose the one coming against him with twenty thousand?

32.text: If he cannot succeed, he will send a representative while the other is still a long way off and ask for terms of peace.

33.text: In the same way therefore not one of you can be my disciple if he does not renounce all his own possessions.

34.text: “Salt is good, but if salt loses its flavor, how can its flavor be restored?

35.text: It is of no value for the soil or for the manure pile; it is to be thrown out. The one who has ears to hear had better listen!”

1.text: Then Jesus told them a parable to show them they should always pray and not lose heart.

2.text: He said, “In a certain city there was a judge who neither feared God nor respected people.

3.text: There was also a widow in that city who kept coming to him and saying, ‘Give me justice against my adversary.’

4.text: For a while he refused, but later on he said to himself, ‘Though I neither fear God nor have regard for people,

5.text: yet because this widow keeps on bothering me, I will give her justice, or in the end she will wear me out by her unending pleas.’”

6.text: And the Lord said, “Listen to what the unrighteous judge says!

7.text: Won’t God give justice to his chosen ones, who cry out to him day and night? Will he delay long to help them?

8.text: I tell you, he will give them justice speedily. Nevertheless, when the Son of Man comes, will he find faith on earth?”

9.text: Jesus also told this parable to some who were confident that they were righteous and looked down on everyone else.

10.text: “Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector.

11.text: The Pharisee stood and prayed about himself like this: ‘God, I thank you that I am not like other people: extortionists, unrighteous people, adulterers – or even like this tax collector.

12.text: I fast twice a week; I give a tenth of everything I get.’

13.text: The tax collector, however, stood far off and would not even look up to heaven, but beat his breast and said, ‘God, be merciful to me, sinner that I am!’

14.text: I tell you that this man went down to his home justified rather than the Pharisee. For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, but he who humbles himself will be exalted.”

15.text: Now people were even bringing their babies to him for him to touch. But when the disciples saw it, they began to scold those who brought them.

16.text: But Jesus called for the children, saying, “Let the little children come to me and do not try to stop them, for the kingdom of God belongs to such as these.

17.text: I tell you the truth, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a child will never enter it.”

18.text: Now a certain ruler asked him, “Good teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?”

19.text: Jesus said to him, “Why do you call me good? No one is good except God alone.

20.text: You know the commandments: ‘Do not commit adultery, do not murder, do not steal, do not give false testimony, honor your father and mother.’”

21.text: The man replied, “I have wholeheartedly obeyed all these laws since my youth.”

22.text: When Jesus heard this, he said to him, “One thing you still lack. Sell all that you have and give the money to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me.”

23.text: But when the man heard this he became very sad, for he was extremely wealthy.

24.text: When Jesus noticed this, he said, “How hard it is for the rich to enter the kingdom of God!

25.text: In fact, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter the kingdom of God.”

26.text: Those who heard this said, “Then who can be saved?”

27.text: He replied, “What is impossible for mere humans is possible for God.”

28.text: And Peter said, “Look, we have left everything we own to follow you!”

29.text: Then Jesus said to them, “I tell you the truth, there is no one who has left home or wife or brothers or parents or children for the sake of God’s kingdom

30.text: who will not receive many times more in this age – and in the age to come, eternal life.”

31.text: Then Jesus took the twelve aside and said to them, “Look, we are going up to Jerusalem, and everything that is written about the Son of Man by the prophets will be accomplished.
