32.text: For he will be handed over to the Gentiles; he will be mocked, mistreated, and spat on.

33.text: They will flog him severely and kill him. Yet on the third day he will rise again.”

34.text: But the twelve understood none of these things. This saying was hidden from them, and they did not grasp what Jesus meant.

35.text: As Jesus approached Jericho, a blind man was sitting by the road begging.

36.text: When he heard a crowd going by, he asked what was going on.

37.text: They told him, “Jesus the Nazarene is passing by.”

38.text: So he called out, “Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!”

39.text: And those who were in front scolded him to get him to be quiet, but he shouted even more, “Son of David, have mercy on me!”

40.text: So Jesus stopped and ordered the beggar to be brought to him. When the man came near, Jesus asked him,

41.text: “What do you want me to do for you?” He replied, “Lord, let me see again.”

42.text: Jesus said to him, “Receive your sight; your faith has healed you.”

43.text: And immediately he regained his sight and followed Jesus, praising God. When all the people saw it, they too gave praise to God.

1.text: Now the Feast of Unleavened Bread, which is called the Passover, was approaching.

2.text: The chief priests and the experts in the law were trying to find some way to execute Jesus, for they were afraid of the people.

3.text: Then Satan entered Judas, the one called Iscariot, who was one of the twelve.

4.text: He went away and discussed with the chief priests and officers of the temple guard how he might betray Jesus, handing him over to them.

5.text: They were delighted and arranged to give him money.

6.text: So Judas agreed and began looking for an opportunity to betray Jesus when no crowd was present.

7.text: Then the day for the feast of Unleavened Bread came, on which the Passover lamb had to be sacrificed.

8.text: Jesus sent Peter and John, saying, “Go and prepare the Passover for us to eat.”

9.text: They said to him, “Where do you want us to prepare it?”

10.text: He said to them, “Listen, when you have entered the city, a man carrying a jar of water will meet you. Follow him into the house that he enters,

11.text: and tell the owner of the house, ‘The Teacher says to you, “Where is the guest room where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?”’

12.text: Then he will show you a large furnished room upstairs. Make preparations there.”

13.text: So they went and found things just as he had told them, and they prepared the Passover.

14.text: Now when the hour came, Jesus took his place at the table and the apostles joined him.

15.text: And he said to them, “I have earnestly desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.

16.text: For I tell you, I will not eat it again until it is fulfilled in the kingdom of God.”

17.text: Then he took a cup, and after giving thanks he said, “Take this and divide it among yourselves.

18.text: For I tell you that from now on I will not drink of the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes.”

19.text: Then he took bread, and after giving thanks he broke it and gave it to them, saying, “This is my body which is given for you. Do this in remembrance of me.”

20.text: And in the same way he took the cup after they had eaten, saying, “This cup that is poured out for you is the new covenant in my blood.

21.text: “But look, the hand of the one who betrays me is with me on the table.

22.text: For the Son of Man is to go just as it has been determined, but woe to that man by whom he is betrayed!”

23.text: So they began to question one another as to which of them it could possibly be who would do this.

24.text: A dispute also started among them over which of them was to be regarded as the greatest.

25.text: So Jesus said to them, “The kings of the Gentiles lord it over them, and those in authority over them are called ‘benefactors.’

26.text: Not so with you; instead the one who is greatest among you must become like the youngest, and the leader like the one who serves.

27.text: For who is greater, the one who is seated at the table, or the one who serves? Is it not the one who is seated at the table? But I am among you as one who serves.

28.text: “You are the ones who have remained with me in my trials.

29.text: Thus I grant to you a kingdom, just as my Father granted to me,

30.text: that you may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom, and you will sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.

31.text: “Simon, Simon, pay attention! Satan has demanded to have you all, to sift you like wheat,

32.text: but I have prayed for you, Simon, that your faith may not fail. When you have turned back, strengthen your brothers.”

33.text: But Peter said to him, “Lord, I am ready to go with you both to prison and to death!”

34.text: Jesus replied, “I tell you, Peter, the rooster will not crow today until you have denied three times that you know me.”

35.text: Then Jesus said to them, “When I sent you out with no money bag, or traveler’s bag, or sandals, you didn’t lack anything, did you?” They replied, “Nothing.”

36.text: He said to them, “But now, the one who has a money bag must take it, and likewise a traveler’s bag too. And the one who has no sword must sell his cloak and buy one.

37.text: For I tell you that this scripture must be fulfilled in me, ‘And he was counted with the transgressors.’ For what is written about me is being fulfilled.”

38.text: So they said, “Look, Lord, here are two swords.” Then he told them, “It is enough.”

39.text: Then Jesus went out and made his way, as he customarily did, to the Mount of Olives, and the disciples followed him.

40.text: When he came to the place, he said to them, “Pray that you will not fall into temptation.”

41.text: He went away from them about a stone’s throw, knelt down, and prayed,

42.text: “Father, if you are willing, take this cup away from me. Yet not my will but yours be done.”

43.text: [Then an angel from heaven appeared to him and strengthened him.

44.text: And in his anguish he prayed more earnestly, and his sweat was like drops of blood falling to the ground.]

45.text: When he got up from prayer, he came to the disciples and found them sleeping, exhausted from grief.

46.text: So he said to them, “Why are you sleeping? Get up and pray that you will not fall into temptation!”

47.text: While he was still speaking, suddenly a crowd appeared, and the man named Judas, one of the twelve, was leading them. He walked up to Jesus to kiss him.

48.text: But Jesus said to him, “Judas, would you betray the Son of Man with a kiss?”

49.text: When those who were around him saw what was about to happen, they said, “Lord, should we use our swords?”

50.text: Then one of them struck the high priest’s slave, cutting off his right ear.

51.text: But Jesus said, “Enough of this!” And he touched the man’s ear and healed him.

52.text: Then Jesus said to the chief priests, the officers of the temple guard, and the elders who had come out to get him, “Have you come out with swords and clubs like you would against an outlaw?

53.text: Day after day when I was with you in the temple courts, you did not arrest me. But this is your hour, and that of the power of darkness!”

54.text: Then they arrested Jesus, led him away, and brought him into the high priest’s house. But Peter was following at a distance.

55.text: When they had made a fire in the middle of the courtyard and sat down together, Peter sat down among them.

56.text: Then a slave girl, seeing him as he sat in the firelight, stared at him and said, “This man was with him too!”

57.text: But Peter denied it: “Woman, I don’t know him!”

58.text: Then a little later someone else saw him and said, “You are one of them too.” But Peter said, “Man, I am not!”

59.text: And after about an hour still another insisted, “Certainly this man was with him, because he too is a Galilean.”

60.text: But Peter said, “Man, I don’t know what you’re talking about!” At that moment, while he was still speaking, a rooster crowed.

61.text: Then the Lord turned and looked straight at Peter, and Peter remembered the word of the Lord, how he had said to him, “Before a rooster crows today, you will deny me three times.”

62.text: And he went outside and wept bitterly.

63.text: Now the men who were holding Jesus under guard began to mock him and beat him.

64.text: They blindfolded him and asked him repeatedly, “Prophesy! Who hit you?”

65.text: They also said many other things against him, reviling him.

66.text: When day came, the council of the elders of the people gathered together, both the chief priests and the experts in the law. Then they led Jesus away to their council

67.text: and said, “If you are the Christ, tell us.” But he said to them, “If I tell you, you will not believe,

68.text: and if I ask you, you will not answer.

69.text: But from now on the Son of Man will be seated at the right hand of the power of God.”

70.text: So they all said, “Are you the Son of God, then?” He answered them, “You say that I am.”

71.text: Then they said, “Why do we need further testimony? We have heard it ourselves from his own lips!”

1.text: The beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.

2.text: As it is written in Isaiah the prophet, “Look, I am sending my messenger ahead of you, who will prepare your way,

3.text: the voice of one shouting in the wilderness, ‘Prepare the way for the Lord, make his paths straight.’”

4.text: In the wilderness John the baptizer began preaching a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.

5.text: People from the whole Judean countryside and all of Jerusalem were going out to him, and he was baptizing them in the Jordan River as they confessed their sins.

6.text: John wore a garment made of camel’s hair with a leather belt around his waist, and he ate locusts and wild honey.

7.text: He proclaimed, “One more powerful than I am is coming after me; I am not worthy to bend down and untie the strap of his sandals.

8.text: I baptize you with water, but he will baptize you with the Holy Spirit.”

9.text: Now in those days Jesus came from Nazareth in Galilee and was baptized by John in the Jordan River.

10.text: And just as Jesus was coming up out of the water, he saw the heavens splitting apart and the Spirit descending on him like a dove.

11.text: And a voice came from heaven: “You are my one dear Son; in you I take great delight.”

12.text: The Spirit immediately drove him into the wilderness.

13.text: He was in the wilderness forty days, enduring temptations from Satan. He was with wild animals, and angels were ministering to his needs.

14.text: Now after John was imprisoned, Jesus went into Galilee and proclaimed the gospel of God.

15.text: He said, “The time is fulfilled and the kingdom of God is near. Repent and believe the gospel!”

16.text: As he went along the Sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and Andrew, Simon’s brother, casting a net into the sea (for they were fishermen).

17.text: Jesus said to them, “Follow me, and I will turn you into fishers of people.”

18.text: They left their nets immediately and followed him.

19.text: Going on a little farther, he saw James, the son of Zebedee, and John his brother in their boat mending nets.

20.text: Immediately he called them, and they left their father Zebedee in the boat with the hired men and followed him.

21.text: Then they went to Capernaum. When the Sabbath came, Jesus went into the synagogue and began to teach.

22.text: The people there were amazed by his teaching, because he taught them like one who had authority, not like the experts in the law.

23.text: Just then there was a man in their synagogue with an unclean spirit, and he cried out,

24.text: “Leave us alone, Jesus the Nazarene! Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are – the Holy One of God!”

25.text: But Jesus rebuked him: “Silence! Come out of him!”

26.text: After throwing him into convulsions, the unclean spirit cried out with a loud voice and came out of him.

27.text: They were all amazed so that they asked each other, “What is this? A new teaching with authority! He even commands the unclean spirits and they obey him.”

28.text: So the news about him spread quickly throughout all the region around Galilee.

29.text: Now as soon as they left the synagogue, they entered Simon and Andrew’s house, with James and John.

30.text: Simon’s mother-in-law was lying down, sick with a fever, so they spoke to Jesus at once about her.

31.text: He came and raised her up by gently taking her hand. Then the fever left her and she began to serve them.

32.text: When it was evening, after sunset, they brought to him all who were sick and demon-possessed.

33.text: The whole town gathered by the door.

34.text: So he healed many who were sick with various diseases and drove out many demons. But he would not permit the demons to speak, because they knew him.

35.text: Then Jesus got up early in the morning when it was still very dark, departed, and went out to a deserted place, and there he spent time in prayer.

36.text: Simon and his companions searched for him.

37.text: When they found him, they said, “Everyone is looking for you.”

38.text: He replied, “Let us go elsewhere, into the surrounding villages, so that I can preach there too. For that is what I came out here to do.”

39.text: So he went into all of Galilee preaching in their synagogues and casting out demons.

40.text: Now a leper came to him and fell to his knees, asking for help. “If you are willing, you can make me clean,” he said.

41.text: Moved with compassion, Jesus stretched out his hand and touched him, saying, “I am willing. Be clean!”

42.text: The leprosy left him at once, and he was clean.

43.text: Immediately Jesus sent the man away with a very strong warning.

44.text: He told him, “See that you do not say anything to anyone, but go, show yourself to a priest, and bring the offering that Moses commanded for your cleansing, as a testimony to them.”

45.text: But as the man went out he began to announce it publicly and spread the story widely, so that Jesus was no longer able to enter any town openly but stayed outside in remote places. Still they kept coming to him from everywhere.

1.text: Then Jesus entered the synagogue again, and a man was there who had a withered hand.

2.text: They watched Jesus closely to see if he would heal him on the Sabbath, so that they could accuse him.

3.text: So he said to the man who had the withered hand, “Stand up among all these people.”

4.text: Then he said to them, “Is it lawful to do good on the Sabbath, or evil, to save a life or destroy it?” But they were silent.

5.text: After looking around at them in anger, grieved by the hardness of their hearts, he said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” He stretched it out, and his hand was restored.

6.text: So the Pharisees went out immediately and began plotting with the Herodians, as to how they could assassinate him.

7.text: Then Jesus went away with his disciples to the sea, and a great multitude from Galilee followed him. And from Judea,

8.text: Jerusalem, a great multitude came to him when they heard about the things he had done.

9.text: Because of the crowd, he told his disciples to have a small boat ready for him so the crowd would not press toward him.

10.text: For he had healed many, so that all who were afflicted with diseases pressed toward him in order to touch him.

11.text: And whenever the unclean spirits saw him, they fell down before him and cried out, “You are the Son of God.”

12.text: But he sternly ordered them not to make him known.

13.text: Now Jesus went up the mountain and called for those he wanted, and they came to him.

14.text: He appointed twelve (whom he named apostles ), so that they would be with him and he could send them to preach

15.text: and to have authority to cast out demons.

16.text: He appointed twelve: To Simon he gave the name Peter;

17.text: to James and his brother John, the sons of Zebedee, he gave the name Boanerges (that is, “sons of thunder”);

18.text: and Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James the son of Alphaeus, Thaddaeus, Simon the Zealot,

19.text: and Judas Iscariot, who betrayed him.

20.text: Now Jesus went home, and a crowd gathered so that they were not able to eat.

21.text: When his family heard this they went out to restrain him, for they said, “He is out of his mind.”

22.text: The experts in the law who came down from Jerusalem said, “He is possessed by Beelzebul,” and, “By the ruler of demons he casts out demons.”

23.text: So he called them and spoke to them in parables: “How can Satan cast out Satan?

24.text: If a kingdom is divided against itself, that kingdom will not be able to stand.

25.text: If a house is divided against itself, that house will not be able to stand.

26.text: And if Satan rises against himself and is divided, he is not able to stand and his end has come.

27.text: But no one is able to enter a strong man’s house and steal his property unless he first ties up the strong man. Then he can thoroughly plunder his house.

28.text: I tell you the truth, people will be forgiven for all sins, even all the blasphemies they utter.

29.text: But whoever blasphemes against the Holy Spirit will never be forgiven, but is guilty of an eternal sin”

30.text: (because they said, “He has an unclean spirit” ).

31.text: Then Jesus’ mother and his brothers came. Standing outside, they sent word to him, to summon him.

32.text: A crowd was sitting around him and they said to him, “Look, your mother and your brothers are outside looking for you.”

33.text: He answered them and said, “Who are my mother and my brothers?”

34.text: And looking at those who were sitting around him in a circle, he said, “Here are my mother and my brothers!

35.text: For whoever does the will of God is my brother and sister and mother.”

1.text: In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.

2.text: Now the earth was without shape and empty, and darkness was over the surface of the watery deep, but the Spirit of God was moving over the surface of the water.

3.text: God said, “Let there be light.” And there was light!

4.text: God saw that the light was good, so God separated the light from the darkness.

5.text: God called the light “day” and the darkness “night.” There was evening, and there was morning, marking the first day.

6.text: God said, “Let there be an expanse in the midst of the waters and let it separate water from water.

7.text: So God made the expanse and separated the water under the expanse from the water above it. It was so.

8.text: God called the expanse “sky.” There was evening, and there was morning, a second day.

9.text: God said, “Let the water under the sky be gathered to one place and let dry ground appear.” It was so.

10.text: God called the dry ground “land” and the gathered waters he called “seas.” God saw that it was good.

11.text: God said, “Let the land produce vegetation: plants yielding seeds according to their kinds, and trees bearing fruit with seed in it according to their kinds.” It was so.

12.text: The land produced vegetation – plants yielding seeds according to their kinds, and trees bearing fruit with seed in it according to their kinds. God saw that it was good.

13.text: There was evening, and there was morning, a third day.

14.text: God said, “Let there be lights in the expanse of the sky to separate the day from the night, and let them be signs to indicate seasons and days and years,

15.text: and let them serve as lights in the expanse of the sky to give light on the earth.” It was so.

16.text: God made two great lights – the greater light to rule over the day and the lesser light to rule over the night. He made the stars also.

17.text: God placed the lights in the expanse of the sky to shine on the earth,

18.text: to preside over the day and the night, and to separate the light from the darkness. God saw that it was good.

19.text: There was evening, and there was morning, a fourth day.

20.text: God said, “Let the water swarm with swarms of living creatures and let birds fly above the earth across the expanse of the sky.”

21.text: God created the great sea creatures and every living and moving thing with which the water swarmed, according to their kinds, and every winged bird according to its kind. God saw that it was good.

22.text: God blessed them and said, “Be fruitful and multiply and fill the water in the seas, and let the birds multiply on the earth.”

23.text: There was evening, and there was morning, a fifth day.

24.text: God said, “Let the land produce living creatures according to their kinds: cattle, creeping things, and wild animals, each according to its kind.” It was so.

25.text: God made the wild animals according to their kinds, the cattle according to their kinds, and all the creatures that creep along the ground according to their kinds. God saw that it was good.

26.text: Then God said, “Let us make humankind in our image, after our likeness, so they may rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air, over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over all the creatures that move on the earth.”

27.text: God created humankind in his own image, in the image of God he created them, male and female he created them.

28.text: God blessed them and said to them, “Be fruitful and multiply! Fill the earth and subdue it! Rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air and every creature that moves on the ground.”

29.text: Then God said, “I now give you every seed-bearing plant on the face of the entire earth and every tree that has fruit with seed in it. They will be yours for food.

30.text: And to all the animals of the earth, and to every bird of the air, and to all the creatures that move on the ground – everything that has the breath of life in it – I give every green plant for food.” It was so.

31.text: God saw all that he had made – and it was very good! There was evening, and there was morning, the sixth day.

1.text: The heavens and the earth were completed with everything that was in them.

2.text: By the seventh day God finished the work that he had been doing, and he ceased on the seventh day all the work that he had been doing.

3.text: God blessed the seventh day and made it holy because on it he ceased all the work that he had been doing in creation.

4.text: This is the account of the heavens and the earth when they were created – when the Lord God made the earth and heavens.

5.text: Now no shrub of the field had yet grown on the earth, and no plant of the field had yet sprouted, for the Lord God had not caused it to rain on the earth, and there was no man to cultivate the ground.

6.text: Springs would well up from the earth and water the whole surface of the ground.

7.text: The Lord God formed the man from the soil of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and the man became a living being.

8.text: The Lord God planted an orchard in the east, in Eden; and there he placed the man he had formed.

9.text: The Lord God made all kinds of trees grow from the soil, every tree that was pleasing to look at and good for food. (Now the tree of life and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil were in the middle of the orchard.)

10.text: Now a river flows from Eden to water the orchard, and from there it divides into four headstreams.

11.text: The name of the first is Pishon; it runs through the entire land of Havilah, where there is gold.

12.text: (The gold of that land is pure; pearls and lapis lazuli are also there).

13.text: The name of the second river is Gihon; it runs through the entire land of Cush.

14.text: The name of the third river is Tigris; it runs along the east side of Assyria. The fourth river is the Euphrates.

15.text: The Lord God took the man and placed him in the orchard in Eden to care for it and to maintain it.

16.text: Then the Lord God commanded the man, “You may freely eat fruit from every tree of the orchard,

17.text: but you must not eat from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, for when you eat from it you will surely die.”

18.text: The Lord God said, “It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make a companion for him who corresponds to him.”

19.text: The Lord God formed out of the ground every living animal of the field and every bird of the air. He brought them to the man to see what he would name them, and whatever the man called each living creature, that was its name.

20.text: So the man named all the animals, the birds of the air, and the living creatures of the field, but for Adam no companion who corresponded to him was found.

21.text: So the Lord God caused the man to fall into a deep sleep, and while he was asleep, he took part of the man’s side and closed up the place with flesh.

22.text: Then the Lord God made a woman from the part he had taken out of the man, and he brought her to the man.

23.text: Then the man said, “This one at last is bone of my bones and flesh of my flesh; this one will be called ‘woman,’ for she was taken out of man.”

24.text: That is why a man leaves his father and mother and unites with his wife, and they become a new family.

25.text: The man and his wife were both naked, but they were not ashamed.

1.text: Now the serpent was more shrewd than any of the wild animals that the Lord God had made. He said to the woman, “Is it really true that God said, ‘You must not eat from any tree of the orchard’?”

2.text: The woman said to the serpent, “We may eat of the fruit from the trees of the orchard;

3.text: but concerning the fruit of the tree that is in the middle of the orchard God said, ‘You must not eat from it, and you must not touch it, or else you will die.’”

4.text: The serpent said to the woman, “Surely you will not die,

5.text: for God knows that when you eat from it your eyes will open and you will be like divine beings who know good and evil.”

6.text: When the woman saw that the tree produced fruit that was good for food, was attractive to the eye, and was desirable for making one wise, she took some of its fruit and ate it. She also gave some of it to her husband who was with her, and he ate it.

7.text: Then the eyes of both of them opened, and they knew they were naked; so they sewed fig leaves together and made coverings for themselves.

8.text: Then the man and his wife heard the sound of the Lord God moving about in the orchard at the breezy time of the day, and they hid from the Lord God among the trees of the orchard.

9.text: But the Lord God called to the man and said to him, “Where are you?”

10.text: The man replied, “I heard you moving about in the orchard, and I was afraid because I was naked, so I hid.”

11.text: And the Lord God said, “Who told you that you were naked? Did you eat from the tree that I commanded you not to eat from?”

12.text: The man said, “The woman whom you gave me, she gave me some fruit from the tree and I ate it.”

13.text: So the Lord God said to the woman, “What is this you have done?” And the woman replied, “The serpent tricked me, and I ate.”

14.text: The Lord God said to the serpent, “Because you have done this, cursed are you above all the wild beasts and all the living creatures of the field! On your belly you will crawl and dust you will eat all the days of your life.

15.text: And I will put hostility between you and the woman and between your offspring and her offspring; her offspring will attack your head, and you will attack her offspring’s heel.”

16.text: To the woman he said, “I will greatly increase your labor pains; with pain you will give birth to children. You will want to control your husband, but he will dominate you.”

17.text: But to Adam he said, “Because you obeyed your wife and ate from the tree about which I commanded you, ‘You must not eat from it,’ cursed is the ground thanks to you; in painful toil you will eat of it all the days of your life.

18.text: It will produce thorns and thistles for you, but you will eat the grain of the field.

19.text: By the sweat of your brow you will eat food until you return to the ground, for out of it you were taken; for you are dust, and to dust you will return.”

20.text: The man named his wife Eve, because she was the mother of all the living.

21.text: The Lord God made garments from skin for Adam and his wife, and clothed them.

22.text: And the Lord God said, “Now that the man has become like one of us, knowing good and evil, he must not be allowed to stretch out his hand and take also from the tree of life and eat, and live forever.”

23.text: So the Lord God expelled him from the orchard in Eden to cultivate the ground from which he had been taken.

24.text: When he drove the man out, he placed on the eastern side of the orchard in Eden angelic sentries who used the flame of a whirling sword to guard the way to the tree of life.

1.text: From Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, to the saints [in Ephesus], the faithful in Christ Jesus.

2.text: Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ!

3.text: Blessed is the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who has blessed us with every spiritual blessing in the heavenly realms in Christ.

4.text: For he chose us in Christ before the foundation of the world that we may be holy and unblemished in his sight in love.

5.text: He did this by predestining us to adoption as his sons through Jesus Christ, according to the pleasure of his will –

6.text: to the praise of the glory of his grace that he has freely bestowed on us in his dearly loved Son.

7.text: In him we have redemption through his blood, the forgiveness of our trespasses, according to the riches of his grace

8.text: that he lavished on us in all wisdom and insight.

9.text: He did this when he revealed to us the secret of his will, according to his good pleasure that he set forth in Christ,

10.text: toward the administration of the fullness of the times, to head up all things in Christ – the things in heaven and the things on earth.

11.text: In Christ we too have been claimed as God’s own possession, since we were predestined according to the one purpose of him who accomplishes all things according to the counsel of his will

12.text: so that we, who were the first to set our hope on Christ, would be to the praise of his glory.

13.text: And when you heard the word of truth (the gospel of your salvation) – when you believed in Christ – you were marked with the seal of the promised Holy Spirit,

14.text: who is the down payment of our inheritance, until the redemption of God’s own possession, to the praise of his glory.

15.text: For this reason, because I have heard of your faith in the Lord Jesus and your love for all the saints,

16.text: I do not cease to give thanks for you when I remember you in my prayers.

17.text: I pray that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of glory, may give you spiritual wisdom and revelation in your growing knowledge of him,

18.text: – since the eyes of your heart have been enlightened – so that you may know what is the hope of his calling, what is the wealth of his glorious inheritance in the saints,

19.text: and what is the incomparable greatness of his power toward us who believe, as displayed in the exercise of his immense strength.

20.text: This power he exercised in Christ when he raised him from the dead and seated him at his right hand in the heavenly realms

21.text: far above every rule and authority and power and dominion and every name that is named, not only in this age but also in the one to come.

22.text: And God put all things under Christ’s feet, and he gave him to the church as head over all things.

23.text: Now the church is his body, the fullness of him who fills all in all.

1.text: And although you were dead in your transgressions and sins,

2.text: in which you formerly lived according to this world’s present path, according to the ruler of the kingdom of the air, the ruler of the spirit that is now energizing the sons of disobedience,

3.text: among whom all of us also formerly lived out our lives in the cravings of our flesh, indulging the desires of the flesh and the mind, and were by nature children of wrath even as the rest…

4.text: But God, being rich in mercy, because of his great love with which he loved us,

5.text: even though we were dead in transgressions, made us alive together with Christ – by grace you are saved! –

6.text: and he raised us up with him and seated us with him in the heavenly realms in Christ Jesus,

7.text: to demonstrate in the coming ages the surpassing wealth of his grace in kindness toward us in Christ Jesus.

8.text: For by grace you are saved through faith, and this is not from yourselves, it is the gift of God;

9.text: it is not from works, so that no one can boast.

10.text: For we are his workmanship, having been created in Christ Jesus for good works that God prepared beforehand so we may do them.

11.text: Therefore remember that formerly you, the Gentiles in the flesh – who are called “uncircumcision” by the so-called “circumcision” that is performed on the body by human hands –

12.text: that you were at that time without the Messiah, alienated from the citizenship of Israel and strangers to the covenants of promise, having no hope and without God in the world.

13.text: But now in Christ Jesus you who used to be far away have been brought near by the blood of Christ.

14.text: For he is our peace, the one who made both groups into one and who destroyed the middle wall of partition, the hostility,

15.text: when he nullified in his flesh the law of commandments in decrees. He did this to create in himself one new man out of two, thus making peace,

16.text: and to reconcile them both in one body to God through the cross, by which the hostility has been killed.

17.text: And he came and preached peace to you who were far off and peace to those who were near,

18.text: so that through him we both have access in one Spirit to the Father.

19.text: So then you are no longer foreigners and noncitizens, but you are fellow citizens with the saints and members of God’s household,

20.text: because you have been built on the foundation of the apostles and prophets, with Christ Jesus himself as the cornerstone.

21.text: In him the whole building, being joined together, grows into a holy temple in the Lord,

22.text: in whom you also are being built together into a dwelling place of God in the Spirit.

1.text: For this reason I, Paul, the prisoner of Christ Jesus for the sake of you Gentiles –

2.text: if indeed you have heard of the stewardship of God’s grace that was given to me for you,

3.text: that by revelation the divine secret was made known to me, as I wrote before briefly.

4.text: When reading this, you will be able to understand my insight into this secret of Christ.

5.text: Now this secret was not disclosed to people in former generations as it has now been revealed to his holy apostles and prophets by the Spirit,

6.text: namely, that through the gospel the Gentiles are fellow heirs, fellow members of the body, and fellow partakers of the promise in Christ Jesus.

7.text: I became a servant of this gospel according to the gift of God’s grace that was given to me by the exercise of his power.

8.text: To me – less than the least of all the saints – this grace was given, to proclaim to the Gentiles the unfathomable riches of Christ

9.text: and to enlighten everyone about God’s secret plan – a secret that has been hidden for ages in God who has created all things.

10.text: The purpose of this enlightenment is that through the church the multifaceted wisdom of God should now be disclosed to the rulers and the authorities in the heavenly realms.

11.text: This was according to the eternal purpose that he accomplished in Christ Jesus our Lord,

12.text: in whom we have boldness and confident access to God because of Christ’s faithfulness.

13.text: For this reason I ask you not to lose heart because of what I am suffering for you, which is your glory.

14.text: For this reason I kneel before the Father,

15.text: from whom every family in heaven and on the earth is named.

16.text: I pray that according to the wealth of his glory he may grant you to be strengthened with power through his Spirit in the inner person,

17.text: that Christ may dwell in your hearts through faith, so that, because you have been rooted and grounded in love,

18.text: you may be able to comprehend with all the saints what is the breadth and length and height and depth,

19.text: and thus to know the love of Christ that surpasses knowledge, so that you may be filled up to all the fullness of God.

20.text: Now to him who by the power that is working within us is able to do far beyond all that we ask or think,

21.text: to him be the glory in the church and in Christ Jesus to all generations, forever and ever. Amen.

1.text: I, therefore, the prisoner for the Lord, urge you to live worthily of the calling with which you have been called,

2.text: with all humility and gentleness, with patience, bearing with one another in love,

3.text: making every effort to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace.

4.text: There is one body and one Spirit, just as you too were called to the one hope of your calling,

5.text: one Lord, one faith, one baptism,

6.text: one God and Father of all, who is over all and through all and in all.

7.text: But to each one of us grace was given according to the measure of the gift of Christ.

8.text: Therefore it says, “When he ascended on high he captured captives; he gave gifts to men.”

9.text: Now what is the meaning of “he ascended,” except that he also descended to the lower regions, namely, the earth?

10.text: He, the very one who descended, is also the one who ascended above all the heavens, in order to fill all things.

11.text: It was he who gave some as apostles, some as prophets, some as evangelists, and some as pastors and teachers,

12.text: to equip the saints for the work of ministry, that is, to build up the body of Christ,

13.text: until we all attain to the unity of the faith and of the knowledge of the Son of God – a mature person, attaining to the measure of Christ’s full stature.

14.text: So we are no longer to be children, tossed back and forth by waves and carried about by every wind of teaching by the trickery of people who craftily carry out their deceitful schemes.

15.text: But practicing the truth in love, we will in all things grow up into Christ, who is the head.

16.text: From him the whole body grows, fitted and held together through every supporting ligament. As each one does its part, the body grows in love.

17.text: So I say this, and insist in the Lord, that you no longer live as the Gentiles do, in the futility of their thinking.

18.text: They are darkened in their understanding, being alienated from the life of God because of the ignorance that is in them due to the hardness of their hearts.

19.text: Because they are callous, they have given themselves over to indecency for the practice of every kind of impurity with greediness.

20.text: But you did not learn about Christ like this,

21.text: if indeed you heard about him and were taught in him, just as the truth is in Jesus.

22.text: You were taught with reference to your former way of life to lay aside the old man who is being corrupted in accordance with deceitful desires,

23.text: to be renewed in the spirit of your mind,

24.text: and to put on the new man who has been created in God’s image – in righteousness and holiness that comes from truth.

25.text: Therefore, having laid aside falsehood, each one of you speak the truth with his neighbor, for we are members of one another.

26.text: Be angry and do not sin; do not let the sun go down on the cause of your anger.

27.text: Do not give the devil an opportunity.

28.text: The one who steals must steal no longer; rather he must labor, doing good with his own hands, so that he may have something to share with the one who has need.

29.text: You must let no unwholesome word come out of your mouth, but only what is beneficial for the building up of the one in need, that it may give grace to those who hear.

30.text: And do not grieve the Holy Spirit of God, by whom you were sealed for the day of redemption.

31.text: You must put away every kind of bitterness, anger, wrath, quarreling, and evil, slanderous talk.

32.text: Instead, be kind to one another, compassionate, forgiving one another, just as God in Christ also forgave you.

1.text: Therefore, be imitators of God as dearly loved children

2.text: and live in love, just as Christ also loved us and gave himself for us, a sacrificial and fragrant offering to God.

3.text: But among you there must not be either sexual immorality, impurity of any kind, or greed, as these are not fitting for the saints.

4.text: Neither should there be vulgar speech, foolish talk, or coarse jesting – all of which are out of character – but rather thanksgiving.

5.text: For you can be confident of this one thing: that no person who is immoral, impure, or greedy (such a person is an idolater) has any inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and God.

6.text: Let nobody deceive you with empty words, for because of these things God’s wrath comes on the sons of disobedience.

7.text: Therefore do not be partakers with them,

8.text: for you were at one time darkness, but now you are light in the Lord. Walk as children of the light –

9.text: for the fruit of the light consists in all goodness, righteousness, and truth –

10.text: trying to learn what is pleasing to the Lord.

11.text: Do not participate in the unfruitful deeds of darkness, but rather expose them.

12.text: For the things they do in secret are shameful even to mention.

13.text: But all things being exposed by the light are made evident.

14.text: For everything made evident is light, and for this reason it says: “Awake, O sleeper! Rise from the dead, and Christ will shine on you!”

15.text: Therefore be very careful how you live – not as unwise but as wise,

16.text: taking advantage of every opportunity, because the days are evil.

17.text: For this reason do not be foolish, but be wise by understanding what the Lord’s will is.

18.text: And do not get drunk with wine, which is debauchery, but be filled by the Spirit,

19.text: speaking to one another in psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs, singing and making music in your hearts to the Lord,

20.text: always giving thanks to God the Father for each other in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ,

21.text: and submitting to one another out of reverence for Christ.

22.text: Wives, submit to your husbands as to the Lord,

23.text: because the husband is the head of the wife as also Christ is the head of the church – he himself being the savior of the body.

24.text: But as the church submits to Christ, so also wives should submit to their husbands in everything.

25.text: Husbands, love your wives just as Christ loved the church and gave himself for her

26.text: to sanctify her by cleansing her with the washing of the water by the word,

27.text: so that he may present the church to himself as glorious – not having a stain or wrinkle, or any such blemish, but holy and blameless.

28.text: In the same way husbands ought to love their wives as their own bodies. He who loves his wife loves himself.

29.text: For no one has ever hated his own body but he feeds it and takes care of it, just as Christ also does the church,

30.text: for we are members of his body.

31.text: For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and will be joined to his wife, and the two will become one flesh.

32.text: This mystery is great – but I am actually speaking with reference to Christ and the church.

33.text: Nevertheless, each one of you must also love his own wife as he loves himself, and the wife must respect her husband.

1.text: Therefore what advantage does the Jew have, or what is the value of circumcision?

2.text: Actually, there are many advantages. First of all, the Jews were entrusted with the oracles of God.

3.text: What then? If some did not believe, does their unbelief nullify the faithfulness of God?

4.text: Absolutely not! Let God be proven true, and every human being shown up as a liar, just as it is written: “so that you will be justified in your words and will prevail when you are judged.”

5.text: But if our unrighteousness demonstrates the righteousness of God, what shall we say? The God who inflicts wrath is not unrighteous, is he? (I am speaking in human terms.)

6.text: Absolutely not! For otherwise how could God judge the world?

7.text: For if by my lie the truth of God enhances his glory, why am I still actually being judged as a sinner?

8.text: And why not say, “Let us do evil so that good may come of it”? – as some who slander us allege that we say. (Their condemnation is deserved!)

9.text: What then? Are we better off? Certainly not, for we have already charged that Jews and Greeks alike are all under sin,

10.text: just as it is written: “There is no one righteous, not even one,

11.text: there is no one who understands, there is no one who seeks God.

12.text: All have turned away, together they have become worthless; there is no one who shows kindness, not even one.”

13.text: “Their throats are open graves, they deceive with their tongues, the poison of asps is under their lips.”

14.text: “Their mouths are full of cursing and bitterness.”

15.text: “Their feet are swift to shed blood,

16.text: ruin and misery are in their paths,

17.text: and the way of peace they have not known.”

18.text: “There is no fear of God before their eyes.”

19.text: Now we know that whatever the law says, it says to those who are under the law, so that every mouth may be silenced and the whole world may be held accountable to God.

20.text: For no one is declared righteous before him by the works of the law, for through the law comes the knowledge of sin.

21.text: But now apart from the law the righteousness of God (which is attested by the law and the prophets) has been disclosed –

22.text: namely, the righteousness of God through the faithfulness of Jesus Christ for all who believe. For there is no distinction,

23.text: for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God.

24.text: But they are justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus.

25.text: God publicly displayed him at his death as the mercy seat accessible through faith. This was to demonstrate his righteousness, because God in his forbearance had passed over the sins previously committed.

26.text: This was also to demonstrate his righteousness in the present time, so that he would be just and the justifier of the one who lives because of Jesus’ faithfulness.

27.text: Where, then, is boasting? It is excluded! By what principle? Of works? No, but by the principle of faith!

28.text: For we consider that a person is declared righteous by faith apart from the works of the law.

29.text: Or is God the God of the Jews only? Is he not the God of the Gentiles too? Yes, of the Gentiles too!

30.text: Since God is one, he will justify the circumcised by faith and the uncircumcised through faith.

31.text: Do we then nullify the law through faith? Absolutely not! Instead we uphold the law.

1.text: What then shall we say that Abraham, our ancestor according to the flesh, has discovered regarding this matter?

2.text: For if Abraham was declared righteous by the works of the law, he has something to boast about – but not before God.

3.text: For what does the scripture say? “Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness*.”

4.text: Now to the one who works, his pay is not credited due to grace but due to obligation.

5.text: But to the one who does not work, but believes in the one who declares the ungodly righteous, his faith is credited as righteousness.

6.text: So even David himself speaks regarding the blessedness of the man to whom God credits righteousness apart from works:

7.text: “Blessed are those whose lawless deeds are forgiven, and whose sins are covered;

8.text: blessed is the one against whom the Lord will never count sin*.”

9.text: Is this blessedness then for the circumcision or also for the uncircumcision? For we say, “faith was credited to Abraham as righteousness.”

10.text: How then was it credited to him? Was he circumcised at the time, or not? No, he was not circumcised but uncircumcised!

11.text: And he received the sign of circumcision as a seal of the righteousness that he had by faith while he was still uncircumcised, so that he would become the father of all those who believe but have never been circumcised, that they too could have righteousness credited to them.

12.text: And he is also the father of the circumcised, who are not only circumcised, but who also walk in the footsteps of the faith that our father Abraham possessed when he was still uncircumcised.

13.text: For the promise to Abraham or to his descendants that he would inherit the world was not fulfilled through the law, but through the righteousness that comes by faith.

14.text: For if they become heirs by the law, faith is empty and the promise is nullified.

15.text: For the law brings wrath, because where there is no law there is no transgression either.

16.text: For this reason it is by faith so that it may be by grace, with the result that the promise may be certain to all the descendants – not only to those who are under the law, but also to those who have the faith of Abraham, who is the father of us all

17.text: (as it is written, “I have made you the father of many nations”). He is our father in the presence of God whom he believed – the God who makes the dead alive and summons the things that do not yet exist as though they already do.

18.text: Against hope Abraham believed in hope with the result that he became the father of many nations according to the pronouncement, “so will your descendants be.”

19.text: Without being weak in faith, he considered his own body as dead (because he was about one hundred years old) and the deadness of Sarah’s womb.

20.text: He did not waver in unbelief about the promise of God but was strengthened in faith, giving glory to God.

21.text: He was fully convinced that what God promised he was also able to do.

22.text: So indeed it was credited to Abraham as righteousness.

23.text: But the statement it was credited to him was not written only for Abraham’s sake,

24.text: but also for our sake, to whom it will be credited, those who believe in the one who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead.

25.text: He was given over because of our transgressions and was raised for the sake of our justification.

1.text: Therefore, since we have been declared righteous by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ,

2.text: through whom we have also obtained access by faith into this grace in which we stand, and we rejoice in the hope of God’s glory.

3.text: Not only this, but we also rejoice in sufferings, knowing that suffering produces endurance,

4.text: and endurance, character, and character, hope.

5.text: And hope does not disappoint, because the love of God has been poured out in our hearts through the Holy Spirit who was given to us.

6.text: For while we were still helpless, at the right time Christ died for the ungodly.

7.text: (For rarely will anyone die for a righteous person, though for a good person perhaps someone might possibly dare to die.)

8.text: But God demonstrates his own love for us, in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.

9.text: Much more then, because we have now been declared righteous by his blood, we will be saved through him from God’s wrath.

10.text: For if while we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of his Son, how much more, since we have been reconciled, will we be saved by his life?

11.text: Not only this, but we also rejoice in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received this reconciliation.

12.text: So then, just as sin entered the world through one man and death through sin, and so death spread to all people because all sinned –

13.text: for before the law was given, sin was in the world, but there is no accounting for sin when there is no law.

14.text: Yet death reigned from Adam until Moses even over those who did not sin in the same way that Adam (who is a type of the coming one) transgressed.

15.text: But the gracious gift is not like the transgression. For if the many died through the transgression of the one man, how much more did the grace of God and the gift by the grace of the one man Jesus Christ multiply to the many!

16.text: And the gift is not like the one who sinned. For judgment, resulting from the one transgression, led to condemnation, but the gracious gift from the many failures led to justification.

17.text: For if, by the transgression of the one man, death reigned through the one, how much more will those who receive the abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness reign in life through the one, Jesus Christ!

18.text: Consequently, just as condemnation for all people came through one transgression, so too through the one righteous act came righteousness leading to life for all people.

19.text: For just as through the disobedience of the one man many were made sinners, so also through the obedience of one man many will be made righteous.

20.text: Now the law came in so that the transgression may increase, but where sin increased, grace multiplied all the more,

21.text: so that just as sin reigned in death, so also grace will reign through righteousness to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.

1.text: What shall we say then? Are we to remain in sin so that grace may increase?

2.text: Absolutely not! How can we who died to sin still live in it?

3.text: Or do you not know that as many as were baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death?

4.text: Therefore we have been buried with him through baptism into death, in order that just as Christ was raised from the dead through the glory of the Father, so we too may live a new life.

5.text: For if we have become united with him in the likeness of his death, we will certainly also be united in the likeness of his resurrection.

6.text: We know that our old man was crucified with him so that the body of sin would no longer dominate us, so that we would no longer be enslaved to sin.

7.text: (For someone who has died has been freed from sin.)

8.text: Now if we died with Christ, we believe that we will also live with him.

9.text: We know that since Christ has been raised from the dead, he is never going to die again; death no longer has mastery over him.

10.text: For the death he died, he died to sin once for all, but the life he lives, he lives to God.

11.text: So you too consider yourselves dead to sin, but alive to God in Christ Jesus.

12.text: Therefore do not let sin reign in your mortal body so that you obey its desires,

13.text: and do not present your members to sin as instruments to be used for unrighteousness, but present yourselves to God as those who are alive from the dead and your members to God as instruments to be used for righteousness.

14.text: For sin will have no mastery over you, because you are not under law but under grace.

15.text: What then? Shall we sin because we are not under law but under grace? Absolutely not!

16.text: Do you not know that if you present yourselves as obedient slaves, you are slaves of the one you obey, either of sin resulting in death, or obedience resulting in righteousness?

17.text: But thanks be to God that though you were slaves to sin, you obeyed from the heart that pattern of teaching you were entrusted to,

18.text: and having been freed from sin, you became enslaved to righteousness.

19.text: (I am speaking in human terms because of the weakness of your flesh.) For just as you once presented your members as slaves to impurity and lawlessness leading to more lawlessness, so now present your members as slaves to righteousness leading to sanctification.

20.text: For when you were slaves of sin, you were free with regard to righteousness.

21.text: So what benefit did you then reap from those things that you are now ashamed of? For the end of those things is death.

22.text: But now, freed from sin and enslaved to God, you have your benefit leading to sanctification, and the end is eternal life.

23.text: For the payoff of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.

1.text: There is therefore now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus.

2.text: For the law of the life-giving Spirit in Christ Jesus has set you free from the law of sin and death.

3.text: For God achieved what the law could not do because it was weakened through the flesh. By sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh and concerning sin, he condemned sin in the flesh,

4.text: so that the righteous requirement of the law may be fulfilled in us, who do not walk according to the flesh but according to the Spirit.

5.text: For those who live according to the flesh have their outlook shaped by the things of the flesh, but those who live according to the Spirit have their outlook shaped by the things of the Spirit.

6.text: For the outlook of the flesh is death, but the outlook of the Spirit is life and peace,

7.text: because the outlook of the flesh is hostile to God, for it does not submit to the law of God, nor is it able to do so.

8.text: Those who are in the flesh cannot please God.

9.text: You, however, are not in the flesh but in the Spirit, if indeed the Spirit of God lives in you. Now if anyone does not have the Spirit of Christ, this person does not belong to him.

10.text: But if Christ is in you, your body is dead because of sin, but the Spirit is your life because of righteousness.

11.text: Moreover if the Spirit of the one who raised Jesus from the dead lives in you, the one who raised Christ from the dead will also make your mortal bodies alive through his Spirit who lives in you.

12.text: So then, brothers and sisters, we are under obligation, not to the flesh, to live according to the flesh

13.text: (for if you live according to the flesh, you will die), but if by the Spirit you put to death the deeds of the body you will live.

14.text: For all who are led by the Spirit of God are the sons of God.

15.text: For you did not receive the spirit of slavery leading again to fear, but you received the Spirit of adoption, by whom we cry, “Abba, Father.”

16.text: The Spirit himself bears witness to our spirit that we are God’s children.

17.text: And if children, then heirs (namely, heirs of God and also fellow heirs with Christ) – if indeed we suffer with him so we may also be glorified with him.

18.text: For I consider that our present sufferings cannot even be compared to the glory that will be revealed to us.

19.text: For the creation eagerly waits for the revelation of the sons of God.

20.text: For the creation was subjected to futility – not willingly but because of God who subjected it – in hope

21.text: that the creation itself will also be set free from the bondage of decay into the glorious freedom of God’s children.

22.text: For we know that the whole creation groans and suffers together until now.

23.text: Not only this, but we ourselves also, who have the firstfruits of the Spirit, groan inwardly as we eagerly await our adoption, the redemption of our bodies.

24.text: For in hope we were saved. Now hope that is seen is not hope, because who hopes for what he sees?

25.text: But if we hope for what we do not see, we eagerly wait for it with endurance.

26.text: In the same way, the Spirit helps us in our weakness, for we do not know how we should pray, but the Spirit himself intercedes for us with inexpressible groanings.

27.text: And he who searches our hearts knows the mind of the Spirit, because the Spirit intercedes on behalf of the saints according to God’s will.

28.text: And we know that all things work together for good for those who love God, who are called according to his purpose,

29.text: because those whom he foreknew he also predestined to be conformed to the image of his Son, that his Son would be the firstborn among many brothers and sisters.

30.text: And those he predestined, he also called; and those he called, he also justified; and those he justified, he also glorified.

31.text: What then shall we say about these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?

32.text: Indeed, he who did not spare his own Son, but gave him up for us all – how will he not also, along with him, freely give us all things?

33.text: Who will bring any charge against God’s elect? It is God who justifies.

34.text: Who is the one who will condemn? Christ is the one who died (and more than that, he was raised), who is at the right hand of God, and who also is interceding for us.

35.text: Who will separate us from the love of Christ? Will trouble, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or danger, or sword?

36.text: As it is written, “For your sake we encounter death all day long; we were considered as sheep to be slaughtered.”

37.text: No, in all these things we have complete victory through him who loved us!

38.text: For I am convinced that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor heavenly rulers, nor things that are present, nor things to come, nor powers,

39.text: nor height, nor depth, nor anything else in creation will be able to separate us from the love of God in Christ Jesus our Lord.

1.text: Brothers and sisters, my heart’s desire and prayer to God on behalf of my fellow Israelites is for their salvation.

2.text: For I can testify that they are zealous for God, but their zeal is not in line with the truth.

3.text: For ignoring the righteousness that comes from God, and seeking instead to establish their own righteousness, they did not submit to God’s righteousness.

4.text: For Christ is the end of the law, with the result that there is righteousness for everyone who believes.

5.text: For Moses writes about the righteousness that is by the law: “The one who does these things will live by them.”

6.text: But the righteousness that is by faith says: “Do not say in your heart, ‘Who will ascend into heaven?’” (that is, to bring Christ down)

7.text: or “Who will descend into the abyss?” (that is, to bring Christ up from the dead).

8.text: But what does it say? “The word is near you, in your mouth and in your heart” (that is, the word of faith that we preach),

9.text: because if you confess with your mouth that Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.

10.text: For with the heart one believes and thus has righteousness and with the mouth one confesses and thus has salvation.

11.text: For the scripture says, “Everyone who believes in him will not be put to shame.”

12.text: For there is no distinction between the Jew and the Greek, for the same Lord is Lord of all, who richly blesses all who call on him.

13.text: For everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.

14.text: How are they to call on one they have not believed in? And how are they to believe in one they have not heard of? And how are they to hear without someone preaching to them ?

15.text: And how are they to preach unless they are sent? As it is written, “How timely is the arrival of those who proclaim the good news*.”

16.text: But not all have obeyed the good news, for Isaiah says, “Lord, who has believed our report?”

17.text: Consequently faith comes from what is heard, and what is heard comes through the preached word of Christ.

18.text: But I ask, have they not heard? Yes, they have: Their voice has gone out to all the earth, and their words to the ends of the world.

19.text: But again I ask, didn’t Israel understand? First Moses says, “I will make you jealous by those who are not a nation; with a senseless nation I will provoke you to anger.”

20.text: And Isaiah is even bold enough to say, “I was found by those who did not seek me; I became well known to those who did not ask for me.”

21.text: But about Israel he says, “All day long I held out my hands to this disobedient and stubborn people!”

1.text: But we who are strong ought to bear with the failings of the weak, and not just please ourselves.

2.text: Let each of us please his neighbor for his good to build him up.

3.text: For even Christ did not please himself, but just as it is written, “The insults of those who insult you have fallen on me.”

4.text: For everything that was written in former times was written for our instruction, so that through endurance and through encouragement of the scriptures we may have hope.

5.text: Now may the God of endurance and comfort give you unity with one another in accordance with Christ Jesus,

6.text: so that together you may with one voice glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.

7.text: Receive one another, then, just as Christ also received you, to God’s glory.

8.text: For I tell you that Christ has become a servant of the circumcised on behalf of God’s truth to confirm the promises made to the fathers,

9.text: and thus the Gentiles glorify God for his mercy. As it is written, “Because of this I will confess you among the Gentiles, and I will sing praises to your name.”

10.text: And again it says: “Rejoice, O Gentiles, with his people.”

11.text: And again, “Praise the Lord all you Gentiles, and let all the peoples praise him.”

12.text: And again Isaiah says, “The root of Jesse will come, and the one who rises to rule over the Gentiles, in him will the Gentiles hope.”

13.text: Now may the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace as you believe in him, so that you may abound in hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.

14.text: But I myself am fully convinced about you, my brothers and sisters, that you yourselves are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge, and able to instruct one another.

15.text: But I have written more boldly to you on some points so as to remind you, because of the grace given to me by God

16.text: to be a minister of Christ Jesus to the Gentiles. I serve the gospel of God like a priest, so that the Gentiles may become an acceptable offering, sanctified by the Holy Spirit.

17.text: So I boast in Christ Jesus about the things that pertain to God.

18.text: For I will not dare to speak of anything except what Christ has accomplished through me in order to bring about the obedience of the Gentiles, by word and deed,

19.text: in the power of signs and wonders, in the power of the Spirit of God. So from Jerusalem even as far as Illyricum I have fully preached the gospel of Christ.

20.text: And in this way I desire to preach where Christ has not been named, so as not to build on another person’s foundation,

21.text: but as it is written: “Those who were not told about him will see, and those who have not heard will understand.”

22.text: This is the reason I was often hindered from coming to you.

23.text: But now there is nothing more to keep me in these regions, and I have for many years desired to come to you

24.text: when I go to Spain. For I hope to visit you when I pass through and that you will help me on my journey there, after I have enjoyed your company for a while.

25.text: But now I go to Jerusalem to minister to the saints.

26.text: For Macedonia and Achaia are pleased to make some contribution for the poor among the saints in Jerusalem.

27.text: For they were pleased to do this, and indeed they are indebted to the Jerusalem saints. For if the Gentiles have shared in their spiritual things, they are obligated also to minister to them in material things.

28.text: Therefore after I have completed this and have safely delivered this bounty to them, I will set out for Spain by way of you,

29.text: and I know that when I come to you I will come in the fullness of Christ’s blessing.

30.text: Now I urge you, brothers and sisters, through our Lord Jesus Christ and through the love of the Spirit, to join fervently with me in prayer to God on my behalf.

31.text: Pray that I may be rescued from those who are disobedient in Judea and that my ministry in Jerusalem may be acceptable to the saints,

32.text: so that by God’s will I may come to you with joy and be refreshed in your company.

33.text: Now may the God of peace be with all of you. Amen.

1.text: Now a certain man, a Pharisee named Nicodemus, who was a member of the Jewish ruling council,

2.text: came to Jesus at night and said to him, “Rabbi, we know that you are a teacher who has come from God. For no one could perform the miraculous signs that you do unless God is with him.”

3.text: Jesus replied, “I tell you the solemn truth, unless a person is born from above, he cannot see the kingdom of God.”

4.text: Nicodemus said to him, “How can a man be born when he is old? He cannot enter his mother’s womb and be born a second time, can he?”

5.text: Jesus answered, “I tell you the solemn truth, unless a person is born of water and spirit, he cannot enter the kingdom of God.

6.text: What is born of the flesh is flesh, and what is born of the Spirit is spirit.

7.text: Do not be amazed that I said to you, ‘You must all be born from above.’

8.text: The wind blows wherever it will, and you hear the sound it makes, but do not know where it comes from and where it is going. So it is with everyone who is born of the Spirit.”

9.text: Nicodemus replied, “How can these things be?”

10.text: Jesus answered, “Are you the teacher of Israel and yet you don’t understand these things?

11.text: I tell you the solemn truth, we speak about what we know and testify about what we have seen, but you people do not accept our testimony.

12.text: If I have told you people about earthly things and you don’t believe, how will you believe if I tell you about heavenly things?

13.text: No one has ascended into heaven except the one who descended from heaven – the Son of Man.

14.text: Just as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of Man be lifted up,

15.text: so that everyone who believes in him may have eternal life.”

16.text: For this is the way God loved the world: He gave his one and only Son, so that everyone who believes in him will not perish but have eternal life.

17.text: For God did not send his Son into the world to condemn the world, but that the world should be saved through him.

18.text: The one who believes in him is not condemned. The one who does not believe has been condemned already, because he has not believed in the name of the one and only Son of God.

19.text: Now this is the basis for judging: that the light has come into the world and people loved the darkness rather than the light, because their deeds were evil.

20.text: For everyone who does evil deeds hates the light and does not come to the light, so that their deeds will not be exposed.

21.text: But the one who practices the truth comes to the light, so that it may be plainly evident that his deeds have been done in God.

22.text: After this, Jesus and his disciples came into Judean territory, and there he spent time with them and was baptizing.

23.text: John was also baptizing at Aenon near Salim, because water was plentiful there, and people were coming to him and being baptized.

24.text: (For John had not yet been thrown into prison.)

25.text: Now a dispute came about between some of John’s disciples and a certain Jew concerning ceremonial washing.

26.text: So they came to John and said to him, “Rabbi, the one who was with you on the other side of the Jordan River, about whom you testified – see, he is baptizing, and everyone is flocking to him!”

27.text: John replied, “No one can receive anything unless it has been given to him from heaven.

28.text: You yourselves can testify that I said, ‘I am not the Christ,’ but rather, ‘I have been sent before him.’

29.text: The one who has the bride is the bridegroom. The friend of the bridegroom, who stands by and listens for him, rejoices greatly when he hears the bridegroom’s voice. This then is my joy, and it is complete.

30.text: He must become more important while I become less important.”

31.text: The one who comes from above is superior to all. The one who is from the earth belongs to the earth and speaks about earthly things. The one who comes from heaven is superior to all.

32.text: He testifies about what he has seen and heard, but no one accepts his testimony.

33.text: The one who has accepted his testimony has confirmed clearly that God is truthful.

34.text: For the one whom God has sent speaks the words of God, for he does not give the Spirit sparingly.

35.text: The Father loves the Son and has placed all things under his authority.

36.text: The one who believes in the Son has eternal life. The one who rejects the Son will not see life, but God’s wrath remains on him.

1.text: Now when Jesus knew that the Pharisees had heard that he was winning and baptizing more disciples than John

2.text: (although Jesus himself was not baptizing, but his disciples were),

3.text: he left Judea and set out once more for Galilee.

4.text: But he had to pass through Samaria.

5.text: Now he came to a Samaritan town called Sychar, near the plot of land that Jacob had given to his son Joseph.

6.text: Jacob’s well was there, so Jesus, since he was tired from the journey, sat right down beside the well. It was about noon.

7.text: A Samaritan woman came to draw water. Jesus said to her, “Give me some water to drink.”

8.text: (For his disciples had gone off into the town to buy supplies. )

9.text: So the Samaritan woman said to him, “How can you – a Jew – ask me, a Samaritan woman, for water to drink?” (For Jews use nothing in common with Samaritans.)

10.text: Jesus answered her, “If you had known the gift of God and who it is who said to you, ‘Give me some water to drink,’ you would have asked him, and he would have given you living water.”

11.text: “Sir,” the woman said to him, “you have no bucket and the well is deep; where then do you get this living water?

12.text: Surely you’re not greater than our ancestor Jacob, are you? For he gave us this well and drank from it himself, along with his sons and his livestock.”

13.text: Jesus replied, “Everyone who drinks some of this water will be thirsty again.

14.text: But whoever drinks some of the water that I will give him will never be thirsty again, but the water that I will give him will become in him a fountain of water springing up to eternal life.”

15.text: The woman said to him, “Sir, give me this water, so that I will not be thirsty or have to come here to draw water.”

16.text: He said to her, “Go call your husband and come back here.”

17.text: The woman replied, “I have no husband.” Jesus said to her, “Right you are when you said, ‘I have no husband,’

18.text: for you have had five husbands, and the man you are living with now is not your husband. This you said truthfully!”

19.text: The woman said to him, “Sir, I see that you are a prophet.

20.text: Our fathers worshiped on this mountain, and you people say that the place where people must worship is in Jerusalem.”

21.text: Jesus said to her, “Believe me, woman, a time is coming when you will worship the Father neither on this mountain nor in Jerusalem.

22.text: You people worship what you do not know. We worship what we know, because salvation is from the Jews.

23.text: But a time is coming – and now is here – when the true worshipers will worship the Father in spirit and truth, for the Father seeks such people to be his worshipers.

24.text: God is spirit, and the people who worship him must worship in spirit and truth.”

25.text: The woman said to him, “I know that Messiah is coming” (the one called Christ); “whenever he comes, he will tell us everything.”

26.text: Jesus said to her, “I, the one speaking to you, am he.”

27.text: Now at that very moment his disciples came back. They were shocked because he was speaking with a woman. However, no one said, “What do you want?” or “Why are you speaking with her?”

28.text: Then the woman left her water jar, went off into the town and said to the people,

29.text: “Come, see a man who told me everything I ever did. Surely he can’t be the Messiah, can he?”

30.text: So they left the town and began coming to him.

31.text: Meanwhile the disciples were urging him, “Rabbi, eat something.”

32.text: But he said to them, “I have food to eat that you know nothing about.”

33.text: So the disciples began to say to one another, “No one brought him anything to eat, did they?”

34.text: Jesus said to them, “My food is to do the will of the one who sent me and to complete his work.

35.text: Don’t you say, ‘There are four more months and then comes the harvest?’ I tell you, look up and see that the fields are already white for harvest!

36.text: The one who reaps receives pay and gathers fruit for eternal life, so that the one who sows and the one who reaps can rejoice together.

37.text: For in this instance the saying is true, ‘One sows and another reaps.’

38.text: I sent you to reap what you did not work for; others have labored and you have entered into their labor.”

39.text: Now many Samaritans from that town believed in him because of the report of the woman who testified, “He told me everything I ever did.”

40.text: So when the Samaritans came to him, they began asking him to stay with them. He stayed there two days,

41.text: and because of his word many more believed.

42.text: They said to the woman, “No longer do we believe because of your words, for we have heard for ourselves, and we know that this one really is the Savior of the world.”

43.text: After the two days he departed from there to Galilee.

44.text: (For Jesus himself had testified that a prophet has no honor in his own country.)

45.text: So when he came to Galilee, the Galileans welcomed him because they had seen all the things he had done in Jerusalem at the feast (for they themselves had gone to the feast).

46.text: Now he came again to Cana there was a certain royal official whose son was sick.

47.text: When he heard that Jesus had come back from Judea to Galilee, he went to him and begged him to come down and heal his son, who was about to die.

48.text: So Jesus said to him, “Unless you people see signs and wonders you will never believe!”

49.text: “Sir,” the official said to him, “come down before my child dies.”

50.text: Jesus told him, “Go home; your son will live.” The man believed the word that Jesus spoke to him, and set off for home.

51.text: While he was on his way down, his slaves met him and told him that his son was going to live.

52.text: So he asked them the time when his condition began to improve, and they told him, “Yesterday at one o’clock in the afternoon the fever left him.”

53.text: Then the father realized that it was the very time Jesus had said to him, “Your son will live,” and he himself believed along with his entire household.

54.text: Jesus did this as his second miraculous sign when he returned from Judea to Galilee.

1.text: But Jesus went to the Mount of Olives.

2.text: Early in the morning he came to the temple courts again. All the people came to him, and he sat down and began to teach them.

3.text: The experts in the law and the Pharisees brought a woman who had been caught committing adultery. They made her stand in front of them
