10.text: By his will we have been made holy through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.

11.text: And every priest stands day after day serving and offering the same sacrifices again and again – sacrifices that can never take away sins.

12.text: But when this priest had offered one sacrifice for sins for all time, he sat down at the right hand of God,

13.text: where he is now waiting until his enemies are made a footstool for his feet.

14.text: For by one offering he has perfected for all time those who are made holy.

15.text: And the Holy Spirit also witnesses to us, for after saying,

16.text: “This is the covenant that I will establish with them after those days, says the Lord. I will put my laws on their hearts and I will inscribe them on their minds,”

17.text: then he says, “Their sins and their lawless deeds I will remember no longer.”

18.text: Now where there is forgiveness of these, there is no longer any offering for sin.

19.text: Therefore, brothers and sisters, since we have confidence to enter the sanctuary by the blood of Jesus,

20.text: by the fresh and living way that he inaugurated for us through the curtain, that is, through his flesh,

21.text: and since we have a great priest over the house of God,

22.text: let us draw near with a sincere heart in the assurance that faith brings, because we have had our hearts sprinkled clean from an evil conscience and our bodies washed in pure water.

23.text: And let us hold unwaveringly to the hope that we confess, for the one who made the promise is trustworthy.

24.text: And let us take thought of how to spur one another on to love and good works,

25.text: not abandoning our own meetings, as some are in the habit of doing, but encouraging each other, and even more so because you see the day drawing near.

26.text: For if we deliberately keep on sinning after receiving the knowledge of the truth, no further sacrifice for sins is left for us,

27.text: but only a certain fearful expectation of judgment and a fury of fire that will consume God’s enemies.

28.text: Someone who rejected the law of Moses was put to death without mercy on the testimony of two or three witnesses.

29.text: How much greater punishment do you think that person deserves who has contempt for the Son of God, and profanes the blood of the covenant that made him holy, and insults the Spirit of grace?

30.text: For we know the one who said, “Vengeance is mine, I will repay,” and again, “The Lord will judge his people.”

31.text: It is a terrifying thing to fall into the hands of the living God.

32.text: But remember the former days when you endured a harsh conflict of suffering after you were enlightened.

33.text: At times you were publicly exposed to abuse and afflictions, and at other times you came to share with others who were treated in that way.

34.text: For in fact you shared the sufferings of those in prison, and you accepted the confiscation of your belongings with joy, because you knew that you certainly had a better and lasting possession.

35.text: So do not throw away your confidence, because it has great reward.

36.text: For you need endurance in order to do God’s will and so receive what is promised.

37.text: For just a little longer and he who is coming will arrive and not delay.

38.text: But my righteous one will live by faith, and if he shrinks back, I take no pleasure in him.

39.text: But we are not among those who shrink back and thus perish, but are among those who have faith and preserve their souls.

1.text: From Simeon Peter, a slave and apostle of Jesus Christ, to those who through the righteousness of our God and Savior, Jesus Christ, have been granted a faith just as precious as ours.

2.text: May grace and peace be lavished on you as you grow in the rich knowledge of God and of Jesus our Lord!

3.text: I can pray this because his divine power has bestowed on us everything necessary for life and godliness through the rich knowledge of the one who called us by his own glory and excellence.

4.text: Through these things he has bestowed on us his precious and most magnificent promises, so that by means of what was promised you may become partakers of the divine nature, after escaping the worldly corruption that is produced by evil desire.

5.text: For this very reason, make every effort to add to your faith excellence, to excellence, knowledge;

6.text: to knowledge, self-control; to self-control, perseverance; to perseverance, godliness;

7.text: to godliness, brotherly affection; to brotherly affection, unselfish love.

8.text: For if these things are really yours and are continually increasing, they will keep you from becoming ineffective and unproductive in your pursuit of knowing our Lord Jesus Christ more intimately.

9.text: But concerning the one who lacks such things – he is blind. That is to say, he is nearsighted, since he has forgotten about the cleansing of his past sins.

10.text: Therefore, brothers and sisters, make every effort to be sure of your calling and election. For by doing this you will never stumble into sin.

11.text: For thus an entrance into the eternal kingdom of our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ, will be richly provided for you.

12.text: Therefore, I intend to remind you constantly of these things even though you know them and are well established in the truth that you now have.

13.text: Indeed, as long as I am in this tabernacle, I consider it right to stir you up by way of a reminder,

14.text: since I know that my tabernacle will soon be removed, because our Lord Jesus Christ revealed this to me.

15.text: Indeed, I will also make every effort that, after my departure, you have a testimony of these things.

16.text: For we did not follow cleverly concocted fables when we made known to you the power and return of our Lord Jesus Christ; no, we were eyewitnesses of his grandeur.

17.text: For he received honor and glory from God the Father, when that voice was conveyed to him by the Majestic Glory: “This is my dear Son, in whom I am delighted.”

18.text: When this voice was conveyed from heaven, we ourselves heard it, for we were with him on the holy mountain.

19.text: Moreover, we possess the prophetic word as an altogether reliable thing. You do well if you pay attention to this as you would to a light shining in a murky place, until the day dawns and the morning star rises in your hearts.

20.text: Above all, you do well if you recognize this: No prophecy of scripture ever comes about by the prophet’s own imagination,

21.text: for no prophecy was ever borne of human impulse; rather, men carried along by the Holy Spirit spoke from God.

1.text: “As for you, son of man, prophesy to the mountains of Israel, and say: ‘O mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord!

2.text: This is what the sovereign Lord says: The enemy has spoken against you, saying “Aha!” and, “The ancient heights have become our property!”’

3.text: So prophesy and say: ‘This is what the sovereign Lord says: Surely because they have made you desolate and crushed you from all directions, so that you have become the property of the rest of the nations, and have become the subject of gossip and slander among the people,

4.text: therefore, O mountains of Israel, hear the word of the sovereign Lord: This is what the sovereign Lord says to the mountains and hills, the ravines and valleys, and to the desolate ruins and the abandoned cities that have become prey and an object of derision to the rest of the nations round about –

5.text: therefore this is what the sovereign Lord says: Surely I have spoken in the fire of my zeal against the rest of the nations, and against all Edom, who with great joy and utter contempt have made my land their property and prey, because of its pasture.’

6.text: “Therefore prophesy concerning the land of Israel, and say to the mountains and hills, the ravines and valleys, ‘This is what the sovereign Lord says: Look, I have spoken in my zeal and in my anger, because you have endured the insults of the nations.

7.text: So this is what the sovereign Lord says: I vow that the nations around you will endure insults as well.

8.text: “‘But you, mountains of Israel, will grow your branches, and bear your fruit for my people Israel; for they will arrive soon.

9.text: For indeed, I am on your side; I will turn to you, and you will be plowed and planted.

10.text: I will multiply your people – the whole house of Israel, all of it. The cities will be populated and the ruins rebuilt.

11.text: I will increase the number of people and animals on you; they will increase and be fruitful. I will cause you to be inhabited as in ancient times, and will do more good for you than at the beginning of your history. Then you will know that I am the Lord.

12.text: I will lead people, my people Israel, across you; they will possess you and you will become their inheritance. No longer will you bereave them of their children.

13.text: “‘This is what the sovereign Lord says: Because they are saying to you, “You are a devourer of men, and bereave your nation of children,”

14.text: therefore you will no longer devour people and no longer bereave your nation of children, declares the sovereign Lord.

15.text: I will no longer subject you to the nations’ insults; no longer will you bear the shame of the peoples, and no longer will you bereave your nation, declares the sovereign Lord.’”

16.text: The word of the Lord came to me:

17.text: “Son of man, when the house of Israel was living on their own land, they defiled it by their behavior and their deeds. In my sight their behavior was like the uncleanness of a woman having her monthly period.

18.text: So I poured my anger on them because of the blood they shed on the land and because of the idols with which they defiled it.

19.text: I scattered them among the nations; they were dispersed throughout foreign countries. In accordance with their behavior and their deeds I judged them.

20.text: But when they arrived in the nations where they went, they profaned my holy name. It was said of them, ‘These are the people of the Lord, yet they have departed from his land.’

21.text: I was concerned for my holy reputation which the house of Israel profaned among the nations where they went.

22.text: “Therefore say to the house of Israel, ‘This is what the sovereign Lord says: It is not for your sake that I am about to act, O house of Israel, but for the sake of my holy reputation which you profaned among the nations where you went.

23.text: I will magnify my great name that has been profaned among the nations, that you have profaned among them. The nations will know that I am the Lord, declares the sovereign Lord, when I magnify myself among you in their sight.

24.text: “‘I will take you from the nations and gather you from all the countries; then I will bring you to your land.

25.text: I will sprinkle you with pure water and you will be clean from all your impurities. I will purify you from all your idols.

26.text: I will give you a new heart, and I will put a new spirit within you. I will remove the heart of stone from your body and give you a heart of flesh.

27.text: I will put my Spirit within you; I will take the initiative and you will obey my statutes and carefully observe my regulations.

28.text: Then you will live in the land I gave to your fathers; you will be my people, and I will be your God.

29.text: I will save you from all your uncleanness. I will call for the grain and multiply it; I will not bring a famine on you.

30.text: I will multiply the fruit of the trees and the produce of the fields, so that you will never again suffer the disgrace of famine among the nations.

31.text: Then you will remember your evil behavior and your deeds which were not good; you will loathe yourselves on account of your sins and your abominable deeds.

32.text: Understand that it is not for your sake I am about to act, declares the sovereign Lord. Be ashamed and embarrassed by your behavior, O house of Israel.

33.text: “‘This is what the sovereign Lord says: In the day I cleanse you from all your sins, I will populate the cities and the ruins will be rebuilt.

34.text: The desolate land will be plowed, instead of being desolate in the sight of everyone who passes by.

35.text: They will say, “This desolate land has become like the garden of Eden; the ruined, desolate, and destroyed cities are now fortified and inhabited.”

36.text: Then the nations which remain around you will know that I, the Lord, have rebuilt the ruins and replanted what was desolate. I, the Lord, have spoken – and I will do it!’

37.text: “This is what the sovereign Lord says: I will allow the house of Israel to ask me to do this for them: I will multiply their people like sheep.

38.text: Like the sheep for offerings, like the sheep of Jerusalem during her appointed feasts, so will the ruined cities be filled with flocks of people. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”

1.text: You foolish Galatians! Who has cast a spell on you? Before your eyes Jesus Christ was vividly portrayed as crucified!

2.text: The only thing I want to learn from you is this: Did you receive the Spirit by doing the works of the law or by believing what you heard?

3.text: Are you so foolish? Although you began with the Spirit, are you now trying to finish by human effort?

4.text: Have you suffered so many things for nothing? – if indeed it was for nothing.

5.text: Does God then give you the Spirit and work miracles among you by your doing the works of the law or by your believing what you heard?

6.text: Just as Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness,

7.text: so then, understand that those who believe are the sons of Abraham.

8.text: And the scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, proclaimed the gospel to Abraham ahead of time, saying, “All the nations will be blessed in you*.”

9.text: So then those who believe are blessed along with Abraham the believer.

10.text: For all who rely on doing the works of the law are under a curse, because it is written, “Cursed is everyone who does not keep on doing everything written in the book of the law.”

11.text: Now it is clear no one is justified before God by the law, because the righteous one will live by faith.

12.text: But the law is not based on faith, but the one who does the works of the law will live by them.

13.text: Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law by becoming a curse for us (because it is written, “Cursed is everyone who hangs on a tree”)

14.text: in order that in Christ Jesus the blessing of Abraham would come to the Gentiles, so that we could receive the promise of the Spirit by faith.

15.text: Brothers and sisters, I offer an example from everyday life: When a covenant has been ratified, even though it is only a human contract, no one can set it aside or add anything to it.

16.text: Now the promises were spoken to Abraham and to his descendant. Scripture does not say, “and to the descendants,” referring to many, but “and to your descendant,” referring to one, who is Christ.

17.text: What I am saying is this: The law that came four hundred thirty years later does not cancel a covenant previously ratified by God, so as to invalidate the promise.

18.text: For if the inheritance is based on the law, it is no longer based on the promise, but God graciously gave it to Abraham through the promise.

19.text: Why then was the law given? It was added because of transgressions, until the arrival of the descendant to whom the promise had been made. It was administered through angels by an intermediary.

20.text: Now an intermediary is not for one party alone, but God is one.

21.text: Is the law therefore opposed to the promises of God? Absolutely not! For if a law had been given that was able to give life, then righteousness would certainly have come by the law.

22.text: But the scripture imprisoned everything and everyone under sin so that the promise could be given – because of the faithfulness of Jesus Christ – to those who believe.

23.text: Now before faith came we were held in custody under the law, being kept as prisoners until the coming faith would be revealed.

24.text: Thus the law had become our guardian until Christ, so that we could be declared righteous by faith.

25.text: But now that faith has come, we are no longer under a guardian.

26.text: For in Christ Jesus you are all sons of God through faith.

27.text: For all of you who were baptized into Christ have clothed yourselves with Christ.

28.text: There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free, there is neither male nor female – for all of you are one in Christ Jesus.

29.text: And if you belong to Christ, then you are Abraham’s descendants, heirs according to the promise.

1.text: For freedom Christ has set us free. Stand firm, then, and do not be subject again to the yoke of slavery.

2.text: Listen! I, Paul, tell you that if you let yourselves be circumcised, Christ will be of no benefit to you at all!

3.text: And I testify again to every man who lets himself be circumcised that he is obligated to obey the whole law.

4.text: You who are trying to be declared righteous by the law have been alienated from Christ; you have fallen away from grace!

5.text: For through the Spirit, by faith, we wait expectantly for the hope of righteousness.

6.text: For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision nor uncircumcision carries any weight – the only thing that matters is faith working through love.

7.text: You were running well; who prevented you from obeying the truth?

8.text: This persuasion does not come from the one who calls you!

9.text: A little yeast makes the whole batch of dough rise!

10.text: I am confident in the Lord that you will accept no other view. But the one who is confusing you will pay the penalty, whoever he may be.

11.text: Now, brothers and sisters, if I am still preaching circumcision, why am I still being persecuted? In that case the offense of the cross has been removed.

12.text: I wish those agitators would go so far as to castrate themselves!

13.text: For you were called to freedom, brothers and sisters; only do not use your freedom as an opportunity to indulge your flesh, but through love serve one another.

14.text: For the whole law can be summed up in a single commandment, namely, “You must love your neighbor as yourself.”

15.text: However, if you continually bite and devour one another, beware that you are not consumed by one another.

16.text: But I say, live by the Spirit and you will not carry out the desires of the flesh.

17.text: For the flesh has desires that are opposed to the Spirit, and the Spirit has desires that are opposed to the flesh, for these are in opposition to each other, so that you cannot do what you want.

18.text: But if you are led by the Spirit, you are not under the law.

19.text: Now the works of the flesh are obvious: sexual immorality, impurity, depravity,

20.text: idolatry, sorcery, hostilities, strife, jealousy, outbursts of anger, selfish rivalries, dissensions, factions,

21.text: envying, murder, drunkenness, carousing, and similar things. I am warning you, as I had warned you before: Those who practice such things will not inherit the kingdom of God!

22.text: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,

23.text: gentleness, and self-control. Against such things there is no law.

24.text: Now those who belong to Christ have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.

25.text: If we live by the Spirit, let us also behave in accordance with the Spirit.

26.text: Let us not become conceited, provoking one another, being jealous of one another.

1.text: So then, my brothers and sisters, dear friends whom I long to see, my joy and crown, stand in the Lord in this way, my dear friends!

2.text: I appeal to Euodia and to Syntyche to agree in the Lord.

3.text: Yes, I say also to you, true companion, help them. They have struggled together in the gospel ministry along with me and Clement and my other coworkers, whose names are in the book of life.

4.text: Rejoice in the Lord always. Again I say, rejoice!

5.text: Let everyone see your gentleness. The Lord is near!

6.text: Do not be anxious about anything. Instead, in every situation, through prayer and petition with thanksgiving, tell your requests to God.

7.text: And the peace of God that surpasses all understanding will guard your hearts and minds in Christ Jesus.

8.text: Finally, brothers and sisters, whatever is true, whatever is worthy of respect, whatever is just, whatever is pure, whatever is lovely, whatever is commendable, if something is excellent or praiseworthy, think about these things.

9.text: And what you learned and received and heard and saw in me, do these things. And the God of peace will be with you.

10.text: I have great joy in the Lord because now at last you have again expressed your concern for me. (Now I know you were concerned before but had no opportunity to do anything.)

11.text: I am not saying this because I am in need, for I have learned to be content in any circumstance.

12.text: I have experienced times of need and times of abundance. In any and every circumstance I have learned the secret of contentment, whether I go satisfied or hungry, have plenty or nothing.

13.text: I am able to do all things through the one who strengthens me.

14.text: Nevertheless, you did well to share with me in my trouble.

15.text: And as you Philippians know, at the beginning of my gospel ministry, when I left Macedonia, no church shared with me in this matter of giving and receiving except you alone.

16.text: For even in Thessalonica on more than one occasion you sent something for my need.

17.text: I do not say this because I am seeking a gift. Rather, I seek the credit that abounds to your account.

18.text: For I have received everything, and I have plenty. I have all I need because I received from Epaphroditus what you sent – a fragrant offering, an acceptable sacrifice, very pleasing to God.

19.text: And my God will supply your every need according to his glorious riches in Christ Jesus.

20.text: May glory be given to God our Father forever and ever. Amen.

21.text: Give greetings to all the saints in Christ Jesus. The brothers with me here send greetings.

22.text: All the saints greet you, especially those who belong to Caesar’s household.

23.text: The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit.

1.text: Where do the conflicts and where do the quarrels among you come from? Is it not from this, from your passions that battle inside you?

2.text: You desire and you do not have; you murder and envy and you cannot obtain; you quarrel and fight. You do not have because you do not ask;

3.text: you ask and do not receive because you ask wrongly, so you can spend it on your passions.

4.text: Adulterers, do you not know that friendship with the world means hostility toward God? So whoever decides to be the world’s friend makes himself God’s enemy.

5.text: Or do you think the scripture means nothing when it says, “The spirit that God caused to live within us has an envious yearning”?

6.text: But he gives greater grace. Therefore it says, “God opposes the proud, but he gives grace to the humble.”

7.text: So submit to God. But resist the devil and he will flee from you.

8.text: Draw near to God and he will draw near to you. Cleanse your hands, you sinners, and make your hearts pure, you double-minded.

9.text: Grieve, mourn, and weep. Turn your laughter into mourning and your joy into despair.

10.text: Humble yourselves before the Lord and he will exalt you.

11.text: Do not speak against one another, brothers and sisters. He who speaks against a fellow believer or judges a fellow believer speaks against the law and judges the law. But if you judge the law, you are not a doer of the law but its judge.

12.text: But there is only one who is lawgiver and judge – the one who is able to save and destroy. On the other hand, who are you to judge your neighbor?

13.text: Come now, you who say, “Today or tomorrow we will go into this or that town and spend a year there and do business and make a profit.”

14.text: You do not know about tomorrow. What is your life like? For you are a puff of smoke that appears for a short time and then vanishes.

15.text: You ought to say instead, “If the Lord is willing, then we will live and do this or that.”

16.text: But as it is, you boast in your arrogance. All such boasting is evil.

17.text: So whoever knows what is good to do and does not do it is guilty of sin.

1.text: Come now, you rich! Weep and cry aloud over the miseries that are coming on you.

2.text: Your riches have rotted and your clothing has become moth-eaten.

3.text: Your gold and silver have rusted and their rust will be a witness against you. It will consume your flesh like fire. It is in the last days that you have hoarded treasure!

4.text: Look, the pay you have held back from the workers who mowed your fields cries out against you, and the cries of the reapers have reached the ears of the Lord of hosts.

5.text: You have lived indulgently and luxuriously on the earth. You have fattened your hearts in a day of slaughter.

6.text: You have condemned and murdered the righteous person, although he does not resist you.

7.text: So be patient, brothers and sisters, until the Lord’s return. Think of how the farmer waits for the precious fruit of the ground and is patient for it until it receives the early and late rains.

8.text: You also be patient and strengthen your hearts, for the Lord’s return is near.

9.text: Do not grumble against one another, brothers and sisters, so that you may not be judged. See, the judge stands before the gates!

10.text: As an example of suffering and patience, brothers and sisters, take the prophets who spoke in the Lord’s name.

11.text: Think of how we regard as blessed those who have endured. You have heard of Job’s endurance and you have seen the Lord’s purpose, that the Lord is full of compassion and mercy.

12.text: And above all, my brothers and sisters, do not swear, either by heaven or by earth or by any other oath. But let your “Yes” be yes and your “No” be no, so that you may not fall into judgment.

13.text: Is anyone among you suffering? He should pray. Is anyone in good spirits? He should sing praises.

14.text: Is anyone among you ill? He should summon the elders of the church, and they should pray for him and anoint him with oil in the name of the Lord.

15.text: And the prayer of faith will save the one who is sick and the Lord will raise him up – and if he has committed sins, he will be forgiven.

16.text: So confess your sins to one another and pray for one another so that you may be healed. The prayer of a righteous person has great effectiveness.

17.text: Elijah was a human being like us, and he prayed earnestly that it would not rain and there was no rain on the land for three years and six months!

18.text: Then he prayed again, and the sky gave rain and the land sprouted with a harvest.

19.text: My brothers and sisters, if anyone among you wanders from the truth and someone turns him back,

20.text: he should know that the one who turns a sinner back from his wandering path will save that person’s soul from death and will cover a multitude of sins.

1.text: When the people saw that Moses delayed in coming down from the mountain, they gathered around Aaron and said to him, “Get up, make us gods that will go before us. As for this fellow Moses, the man who brought us up from the land of Egypt, we do not know what has become of him!”

2.text: So Aaron said to them, “Break off the gold earrings that are on the ears of your wives, your sons, and your daughters, and bring them to me.”

3.text: So all the people broke off the gold earrings that were on their ears and brought them to Aaron.

4.text: He accepted the gold from them, fashioned it with an engraving tool, and made a molten calf. Then they said, “These are your gods, O Israel, who brought you up out of Egypt.”

5.text: When Aaron saw this, he built an altar before it, and Aaron made a proclamation and said, “Tomorrow will be a feast to the Lord.”

6.text: So they got up early on the next day and offered up burnt offerings and brought peace offerings, and the people sat down to eat and drink, and they rose up to play.

7.text: The Lord spoke to Moses: “Go quickly, descend, because your people, whom you brought up from the land of Egypt, have acted corruptly.

8.text: They have quickly turned aside from the way that I commanded them – they have made for themselves a molten calf and have bowed down to it and sacrificed to it and said, ‘These are your gods, O Israel, which brought you up from the land of Egypt.’”

9.text: Then the Lord said to Moses: “I have seen this people. Look what a stiff-necked people they are!

10.text: So now, leave me alone so that my anger can burn against them and I can destroy them, and I will make from you a great nation.”

11.text: But Moses sought the favor of the Lord his God and said, “O Lord, why does your anger burn against your people, whom you have brought out from the land of Egypt with great power and with a mighty hand?

12.text: Why should the Egyptians say, ‘For evil he led them out to kill them in the mountains and to destroy them from the face of the earth’? Turn from your burning anger, and relent of this evil against your people.

13.text: Remember Abraham, Isaac, and Israel your servants, to whom you swore by yourself and told them, ‘I will multiply your descendants like the stars of heaven, and all this land that I have spoken about I will give to your descendants, and they will inherit it forever.’”

14.text: Then the Lord relented over the evil that he had said he would do to his people.

15.text: Moses turned and went down from the mountain with the two tablets of the testimony in his hands. The tablets were written on both sides – they were written on the front and on the back.

16.text: Now the tablets were the work of God, and the writing was the writing of God, engraved on the tablets.

17.text: When Joshua heard the noise of the people as they shouted, he said to Moses, “It is the sound of war in the camp!”

18.text: Moses said, “It is not the sound of those who shout for victory, nor is it the sound of those who cry because they are overcome, but the sound of singing I hear.”

19.text: When he approached the camp and saw the calf and the dancing, Moses became extremely angry. He threw the tablets from his hands and broke them to pieces at the bottom of the mountain.

20.text: He took the calf they had made and burned it in the fire, ground it to powder, poured it out on the water, and made the Israelites drink it.

21.text: Moses said to Aaron, “What did this people do to you, that you have brought on them so great a sin?”

22.text: Aaron said, “Do not let your anger burn hot, my lord; you know these people, that they tend to evil.

23.text: They said to me, ‘Make us gods that will go before us, for as for this fellow Moses, the man who brought us up out of the land of Egypt, we do not know what has happened to him.’

24.text: So I said to them, ‘Whoever has gold, break it off.’ So they gave it to me, and I threw it into the fire, and this calf came out.”

25.text: Moses saw that the people were running wild, for Aaron had let them get completely out of control, causing derision from their enemies.

26.text: So Moses stood at the entrance of the camp and said, “Whoever is for the Lord, come to me.” All the Levites gathered around him,

27.text: and he said to them, “Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel, ‘Each man fasten his sword on his side, and go back and forth from entrance to entrance throughout the camp, and each one kill his brother, his friend, and his neighbor.’”

28.text: The Levites did what Moses ordered, and that day about three thousand men of the people died.

29.text: Moses said, “You have been consecrated today for the Lord, for each of you was against his son or against his brother, so he has given a blessing to you today.”

30.text: The next day Moses said to the people, “You have committed a very serious sin, but now I will go up to the Lord – perhaps I can make atonement on behalf of your sin.”

31.text: So Moses returned to the Lord and said, “Alas, this people has committed a very serious sin, and they have made for themselves gods of gold.

32.text: But now, if you will forgive their sin…, but if not, wipe me out from your book that you have written.”

33.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Whoever has sinned against me – that person I will wipe out of my book.

34.text: So now go, lead the people to the place I have spoken to you about. See, my angel will go before you. But on the day that I punish, I will indeed punish them for their sin.”

35.text: And the Lord sent a plague on the people because they had made the calf – the one Aaron made.

1.text: For you yourselves know, brothers and sisters, about our coming to you – it has not proven to be purposeless.

2.text: But although we suffered earlier and were mistreated in Philippi, as you know, we had the courage in our God to declare to you the gospel of God in spite of much opposition.

3.text: For the appeal we make does not come from error or impurity or with deceit,

4.text: but just as we have been approved by God to be entrusted with the gospel, so we declare it, not to please people but God, who examines our hearts.

5.text: For we never appeared with flattering speech, as you know, nor with a pretext for greed – God is our witness –

6.text: nor to seek glory from people, either from you or from others,

7.text: although we could have imposed our weight as apostles of Christ; instead we became little children among you. Like a nursing mother caring for her own children,

8.text: with such affection for you we were happy to share with you not only the gospel of God but also our own lives, because you had become dear to us.

9.text: For you recall, brothers and sisters, our toil and drudgery: By working night and day so as not to impose a burden on any of you, we preached to you the gospel of God.

10.text: You are witnesses, and so is God, as to how holy and righteous and blameless our conduct was toward you who believe.

11.text: As you know, we treated each one of you as a father treats his own children,

12.text: exhorting and encouraging you and insisting that you live in a way worthy of God who calls you to his own kingdom and his glory.

13.text: And so we too constantly thank God that when you received God’s message that you heard from us, you accepted it not as a human message, but as it truly is, God’s message, which is at work among you who believe.

14.text: For you became imitators, brothers and sisters, of God’s churches in Christ Jesus that are in Judea, because you too suffered the same things from your own countrymen as they in fact did from the Jews,

15.text: who killed both the Lord Jesus and the prophets and persecuted us severely. They are displeasing to God and are opposed to all people,

16.text: because they hinder us from speaking to the Gentiles so that they may be saved. Thus they constantly fill up their measure of sins, but wrath has come upon them completely.

17.text: But when we were separated from you, brothers and sisters, for a short time (in presence, not in affection) we became all the more fervent in our great desire to see you in person.

18.text: For we wanted to come to you (I, Paul, in fact tried again and again) but Satan thwarted us.

19.text: For who is our hope or joy or crown to boast of before our Lord Jesus at his coming? Is it not of course you?

20.text: For you are our glory and joy!

1.text: Now on the topic of times and seasons, brothers and sisters, you have no need for anything to be written to you.

2.text: For you know quite well that the day of the Lord will come in the same way as a thief in the night.

3.text: Now when they are saying, “There is peace and security,” then sudden destruction comes on them, like labor pains on a pregnant woman, and they will surely not escape.

4.text: But you, brothers and sisters, are not in the darkness for the day to overtake you like a thief would.

5.text: For you all are sons of the light and sons of the day. We are not of the night nor of the darkness.

6.text: So then we must not sleep as the rest, but must stay alert and sober.

7.text: For those who sleep, sleep at night and those who get drunk are drunk at night.

8.text: But since we are of the day, we must stay sober by putting on the breastplate of faith and love and as a helmet our hope for salvation.

9.text: For God did not destine us for wrath but for gaining salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ.

10.text: He died for us so that whether we are alert or asleep we will come to life together with him.

11.text: Therefore encourage one another and build up each other, just as you are in fact doing.

12.text: Now we ask you, brothers and sisters, to acknowledge those who labor among you and preside over you in the Lord and admonish you,

13.text: and to esteem them most highly in love because of their work. Be at peace among yourselves.

14.text: And we urge you, brothers and sisters, admonish the undisciplined, comfort the discouraged, help the weak, be patient toward all.

15.text: See that no one pays back evil for evil to anyone, but always pursue what is good for one another and for all.

16.text: Always rejoice,

17.text: constantly pray,

18.text: in everything give thanks. For this is God’s will for you in Christ Jesus.

19.text: Do not extinguish the Spirit.

20.text: Do not treat prophecies with contempt.

21.text: But examine all things; hold fast to what is good.

22.text: Stay away from every form of evil.

23.text: Now may the God of peace himself make you completely holy and may your spirit and soul and body be kept entirely blameless at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.

24.text: He who calls you is trustworthy, and he will in fact do this.

25.text: Brothers and sisters, pray for us too.

26.text: Greet all the brothers and sisters with a holy kiss.

27.text: I call on you solemnly in the Lord to have this letter read to all the brothers and sisters.

28.text: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.

1.text: Now when Sanballat heard that we were rebuilding the wall he became angry and was quite upset. He derided the Jews,

2.text: and in the presence of his colleagues and the army of Samaria he said, “What are these feeble Jews doing? Will they be left to themselves? Will they again offer sacrifice? Will they finish this in a day? Can they bring these burnt stones to life again from piles of dust?”

3.text: Then Tobiah the Ammonite, who was close by, said, “If even a fox were to climb up on what they are building, it would break down their wall of stones!”

4.text: Hear, O our God, for we are despised! Return their reproach on their own head! Reduce them to plunder in a land of exile!

5.text: Do not cover their iniquity, and do not wipe out their sin from before them. For they have bitterly offended the builders!

6.text: So we rebuilt the wall, and the entire wall was joined together up to half its height. The people were enthusiastic in their work.

7.text: When Sanballat, Tobiah, the Arabs, the Ammonites, and the people of Ashdod heard that the restoration of the walls of Jerusalem had moved ahead and that the breaches had begun to be closed, they were very angry.

8.text: All of them conspired together to move with armed forces against Jerusalem and to create a disturbance in it.

9.text: So we prayed to our God and stationed a guard to protect against them both day and night.

10.text: Then those in Judah said, “The strength of the laborers has failed! The debris is so great that we are unable to rebuild the wall.”

11.text: Our adversaries also boasted, “Before they are aware or anticipate anything, we will come in among them and kill them, and we will bring this work to a halt!”

12.text: So it happened that the Jews who were living near them came and warned us repeatedly about all the schemes they were plotting against us.

13.text: So I stationed people at the lower places behind the wall in the exposed places. I stationed the people by families, with their swords, spears, and bows.

14.text: When I had made an inspection, I stood up and said to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people, “Don’t be afraid of them. Remember the great and awesome Lord, and fight on behalf of your brothers, your sons, your daughters, your wives, and your families!”

15.text: It so happened that when our adversaries heard that we were aware of these matters, God frustrated their intentions. Then all of us returned to the wall, each to his own work.

16.text: From that day forward, half of my men were doing the work and half of them were taking up spears, shields, bows, and body armor. Now the officers were behind all the people of Judah

17.text: who were rebuilding the wall. Those who were carrying loads did so by keeping one hand on the work and the other on their weapon.

18.text: The builders to a man had their swords strapped to their sides while they were building. But the trumpeter remained with me.

19.text: I said to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people, “The work is demanding and extensive, and we are spread out on the wall, far removed from one another.

20.text: Wherever you hear the sound of the trumpet, gather there with us. Our God will fight for us!”

21.text: So we worked on, with half holding spears, from dawn till dusk.

22.text: At that time I instructed the people, “Let every man and his coworker spend the night in Jerusalem and let them be guards for us by night and workers by day.

23.text: We did not change clothes – not I, nor my relatives, nor my workers, nor the watchmen who were with me. Each had his weapon, even when getting a drink of water.

1.text: After this I saw four angels standing at the four corners of the earth, holding back the four winds of the earth so no wind could blow on the earth, on the sea, or on any tree.

2.text: Then I saw another angel ascending from the east, who had the seal of the living God. He shouted out with a loud voice to the four angels who had been given permission to damage the earth and the sea:

3.text: “Do not damage the earth or the sea or the trees until we have put a seal on the foreheads of the servants of our God.”

4.text: Now I heard the number of those who were marked with the seal, one hundred and forty-four thousand, sealed from all the tribes of the people of Israel:

5.text: From the tribe of Judah, twelve thousand were sealed, from the tribe of Reuben, twelve thousand, from the tribe of Gad, twelve thousand,

6.text: from the tribe of Asher, twelve thousand, from the tribe of Naphtali, twelve thousand, from the tribe of Manasseh, twelve thousand,

7.text: from the tribe of Simeon, twelve thousand, from the tribe of Levi, twelve thousand, from the tribe of Issachar, twelve thousand,

8.text: from the tribe of Zebulun, twelve thousand, from the tribe of Joseph, twelve thousand, from the tribe of Benjamin, twelve thousand were sealed.

9.text: After these things I looked, and here was an enormous crowd that no one could count, made up of persons from every nation, tribe, people, and language, standing before the throne and before the Lamb dressed in long white robes, and with palm branches in their hands.

10.text: They were shouting out in a loud voice, “Salvation belongs to our God, to the one seated on the throne, and to the Lamb!”

11.text: And all the angels stood there in a circle around the throne and around the elders and the four living creatures, and they threw themselves down with their faces to the ground before the throne and worshiped God,

12.text: saying, “Amen! Praise and glory, and wisdom and thanksgiving, and honor and power and strength be to our God for ever and ever. Amen!”

13.text: Then one of the elders asked me, “These dressed in long white robes – who are they and where have they come from?”

14.text: So I said to him, “My lord, you know the answer.” Then he said to me, “These are the ones who have come out of the great tribulation. They have washed their robes and made them white in the blood of the Lamb!

15.text: For this reason they are before the throne of God, and they serve him day and night in his temple, and the one seated on the throne will shelter them.

16.text: They will never go hungry or be thirsty again, and the sun will not beat down on them, nor any burning heat,

17.text: because the Lamb in the middle of the throne will shepherd them and lead them to springs of living water, and God will wipe away every tear from their eyes.”
